column13: hidpp10: Fix getting current resolution on G9
column20:
On the G9 the response to a 0x63 is a short report. The G9 does
not have individual resolutions for X and Y and thus only needs
to report a single value.
The set version of 0x63 should probably also be updated. However,
while my testing of such a change worked better than with long
reports there are still strange side effects of setting resolution,
like turning off all the LED's. LGS also seems to do a full profile
read/write instead of using 0x63 when changing the resolution.

read/write instead of using 0x63 when changing the resolution.

column20:
Designates a device that can be queried for the current configuration. Some
devices lack this ability so we rely on the caller to upload a known
configuration to the device before we can really proceed.
Set by default, devices without that capability should be the exception, not
the norm.
This patch just adds the capability, actual handling for this needs to be
added when we add the first device without this capability.
Signed-off-by: Peter Hutterer peter.hutterer@who-t.net

But at least this way we bind the driver immediately.

column13: Add a configure option for valgrind
column20:

is present.
Signed-off-by: Stephen Kitt steve@sk2.org
column21:
On Sun, 18 Sep 2016 17:05:56 -0700, Peter Hutterer notifications@github.com
wrote:

what platform has a broken valgrind

All the MIPSen currently, and ARMv7 (although there's a patch for that) ...

but still needs access to gaming mice?

... and from a strictly user-based point of view, none of them need access to
gaming mice (one could argue about mips64el but no). I'm looking at this from
a package maintainer's perspective though, in Debian — and we try to build
everything on all our platforms.

plus, valgrind is only used for the tests anyway (and they're mostly
broken/insufficient right now)

I know, but I like to run upstream tests during builds, it helps shake bugs
out...
I don't mind carrying this in Debian only, I thought it good form to submit
the patch upstream but I know that means pushing the burden on you. There are
other ways of working around the issue but IMO they make the builds more
annoying (especially for local builds — I don't like having a build which
behaves differently depending on what's installed, and build-conflicts end up
being annoying).
Regards,
Stephen

column21: hmm. I think it'd be better if you could carry this in debian. One glorious day in the future we'll have a working valgrind on those platforms and everything will be fine, but once we merge this option we'll have to keep it around forever. Given this is a bit of a niche case and we're already badly ETIME on libratbag anyway, i'd prefer not to have this one, sorry.

column20:
This contains the new driver for the G.Skill MX780 mouse, and implements all of the functionality that libratbag presently supports. In addition, we add a "reset" capability to libratbag that allows one to request that the mouse reset a profile to manufacturer's default. The main reason for this functionality is because this mouse gets a little upset if it has an improperly written profile, and the windows G.Skill configuration program is actually broken enough that I wasn't able to rely on just using that for resetting profiles.
I'm going to probably start working on additional features as well such as hooking the refresh rate in libratbag up to something, liftoff value support (since it seems to be a common enough function), etc. but for now this seems pretty good :).
column21:
This contains the new driver for the G.Skill MX780 mouse, and implements all of the functionality that libratbag presently supports. In addition, we add a "reset" capability to libratbag that allows one to request that the mouse reset a profile to manufacturer's default. The main reason for this functionality is because this mouse gets a little upset if it has an improperly written profile, and the windows G.Skill configuration program is actually broken enough that I wasn't able to rely on just using that for resetting profiles.
I'm going to probably start working on additional features as well such as hooking the refresh rate in libratbag up to something, liftoff value support (since it seems to be a common enough function), etc. but for now this seems pretty good :).

column13: Add driver for the Logitech G300/G300s
column20:
Supports the common functionality exposed by libratbag:

selecting profile 1-3 (profiles cannot be disabled)
selecting resolution 1-4 (can also not be disabled)
report frequency
default resolution per profile
button actions: mouse button numbers or key+modifier
(modifiers are just a bit field and can easly be set
in the driver, but not included as libratbag does not
support it yet)
LEDs are not yet hooked up but are just a table of 7
different predifined colors.
Seting active profile and resolution are both implemented
but only profile activation is in use. The resolution
activation code is commented until supported from libratbag
itself.

The G300 has an unusual way of numbering buttons:
Left:1, Right:2, Middle: 3
The purpose of report type 0xF2 is not known.

column21:
Note that the driver is added to the autodetection for logitech mice that support neither HID++ 1 or 2. Specifically it will be used for any mouse with a report ID 0xF1. This might make it useful for e.g. the G600 and other non-HID++ mice. However, it does specifically not work for the G400s that I have. That was the reason I did not give the driver a generic name. Let me know if I should rename the driver.
I will see what I can do about getting a G600 to test - and perhaps extend the driver to support if relevant.

column21:
I pushed a commit that deals with most comments. I am still thinking about a good name for the driver. It is only relevant for the G300 and G600. I have a few other unsupported logitech mice but they will not be supported by this driver as they do not even use HID :(. What about logitech-hid as a name for this one?
The code to get the current profile now uses the LED color code. This is not ideal as two profiles can use the same color. I don't see any other way to get it though.

column21:
I pushed a commit that deals with most comments. I am still thinking about a good name for the driver. It is only relevant for the G300 and G600. I have a few other unsupported logitech mice but they will not be supported by this driver as they do not even use HID :(. What about logitech-hid as a name for this one?

Nah. logitech-hid would also match HID++ which uses HID too. Just keep g300, we'll add support for g600 in it, and see how it goes for other devices if there is a need. People just need to know that G600 and G300 are somewhat equivalent.

The code to get the current profile now uses the LED color code. This is not ideal as two profiles can use the same color. I don't see any other way to get it though.

I think it's a hardware limitation you can't defeat. IIRC, if you set 2 profiles with the same color in LGS, you are screwed too and you can't access the second profile ;)
Please squash the update in the initial commit and we'll take this one directly.

column13: Update report rate on all resolutions if needed
column20:
Without the capability RATBAG_RESOLUTION_CAP_INDIVIDUAL_REPORT_RATE we should update the report rate on all resolutions.
As far as I can see we do not have per-resolution report rate on any of the drivers. The API exposes the report rate on the resolutions though, so we need to keep on supporting that. The new code is a bit messy. Should we have a per-profile variable to use when the capability is not set? Or is it worse to have a variable on both profile and resolutions then?
column21:

column13: Internally export some HID++ constants for being able to reuse them in different projects
column20:
This is mostly just HIDPP_ prefixing and shuffling around some defines.
Looking at the fwupd code, it seems necessary to also export the HID++1.0 registers and HID++2.0 feature pages, but I not entirely sure about it given that now we have 3 places to put the protocol data: hidppX0.c, hidppX0.h, hidpp-constants.h.
But OTOH, I don't think we should put the individual commands in hidpp-constants.h.
Thoughts?

This is mostly just HIDPP_ prefixing and shuffling around some defines.
Looking at the fwupd code, it seems necessary to also export the HID++1.0 registers and HID++2.0 feature pages, but I not entirely sure about it given that now we have 3 places to put the protocol data: hidppX0.c, hidppX0.h, hidpp-constants.h.
But OTOH, I don't think we should put the individual commands in hidpp-constants.h.
Thoughts?
column21: ok, the code itself looks good, but I haven't merged it, I'm just not that happy about the hidpp-constants.h itself. If we have a header that keeps both, just name it hidpp.h and move everything there. Otherwise, if we can separate the two enough, make a hidpp10.h and hidpp20.h (and move the internal ones) but tbh I think a single header is good enough here, so this just comes down to a rename now. I'd like the actual constants prefixed with hidpp10 and hidpp20 to avoid accidentally mixing them, with hidpp constants being truly generic across both versions. That's annoying to do and to type, but I think long term it should pay off. hopefully, maybe.

column21:
If you prefer, I could fix the values without adding the cycle down actions.
I am not sure about its usefulness, but since there was "cycle up", it felt right to add "cycle down". If you don't care about the direction, maybe it should simply be called "cycle".
While we are discussing this, I should add there is also a special action to switch to a specific profile by its index. It is useful on the G500 where it can replace the cycle action that does not work. I am not sure how it could be added because of the profile index (maybe by hard-coding the first n profiles, or simulating the profile cycle with it).
For more information, see the updated documentation.

So I'd say if we want to expose it, stick to "ratchet mode switch", as in the PR.

column13: Add more button scancodes to driver-logitech-g300
column20:
According to what the ratslap guy figured out setting the buttons to 0x06-0x09 works fine.
Tested it on my G300S, it works.
Button 9 (0x118) is not defined in linux/input-event-codes.h, but is detected by evtest (though without a nice label), and it does make it through to Xorg (shows up as button 13 in xev).

column13: Remove auto-detection of features from configure.ac
column20:
We only have two auto-detected dependencies, for documentation and tests. During the work with meson I realised this is not really a good solution. Our dependencies should be well-defined for what is considered 'normal' and explicitly defined for any deviation from that normal build.
The normal build includes docs and tests, because we expect developers to find errors in either. A distribution build may exclude either or both, but it should be explicitly specified by the distribution rather than having our build system guess what's not needed.
So this PR removes the auto-detection for doc/test builds and replaces them with a default enabled.
column21:
We only have two auto-detected dependencies, for documentation and tests. During the work with meson I realised this is not really a good solution. Our dependencies should be well-defined for what is considered 'normal' and explicitly defined for any deviation from that normal build.
The normal build includes docs and tests, because we expect developers to find errors in either. A distribution build may exclude either or both, but it should be explicitly specified by the distribution rather than having our build system guess what's not needed.
So this PR removes the auto-detection for doc/test builds and replaces them with a default enabled.

column21: tbh, I'd rather go the other way round and s/breath/breathing/. Reason is that "breathing" is fairly well understood (in, out, in, out, at least usually ;) whereas "breath" is fairly ambiguous - it doesn't describe a continuous activity. And it has bad connotations (e.g. bad breath). Mind swapping this around wherever it says breath instead of breathing?

column13: hidpp20: take into account sectors on 16bits
column20:
First part of fixing #122.
Still missing the dynamically allocation of the sector size, but at least now the hidpp low level calls are correct.
Currently the G402 will not work with libratbag if the sector size is different because we reject any device that has a sector size different than 256.

column13: Adds new Artwork for Logitech G9 and update text and resolution in other svgs
column20:
This PR adds a new artwork for Logitech G9 and updates text in some svg to 12 pt as per read-me to keep consistency. The default resolution in Inkscape (0.92) was changed from 90dpi to 96dpi, to match the CSS standard, so the older svgs are adjusted accordingly.
Thank you
column21:
This PR adds a new artwork for Logitech G9 and updates text in some svg to 12 pt as per read-me to keep consistency. The default resolution in Inkscape (0.92) was changed from 90dpi to 96dpi, to match the CSS standard, so the older svgs are adjusted accordingly.
Thank you

column20:
During a discussion I had with Jakub Steiner he suggested we use toned-down device SVGs instead. Both @whot and I like this approach, so let's discuss this with the rest! This is a first device he did for us, which is the G403 that I own so I can use it while working on Piper.
The mockups aren't entirely up-to-date (will fix that tonight or tomorrow, most likely) but this is where we're going (that's still proof of concept code that I'll extend in the next few days). As you can see, we will need to retrieve some coordinates from the SVG to place the labels. This is why I also updated the guidelines. I also made the canvas size smaller (simply took what Jakub gave me, it looks good) which noticeably increases performance when opening and resizing Piper.

I am a little bit concerned the " G" is too close to the real Logitech logo. IIRC we put as a requirement to not have any copyrighted material, and even if the shape of the mouse has a lot of chances of being copyrighted, having the actual logo is a little bit more worrying.
Please change this into something else (circle maybe), and we can merge the PR.

column21:
Look what we've got: https://github.com/gnome-design-team/gnome-mockups/tree/master/libratbag/assets

Nice!
But there are few errors on those SVGs (not easy to find out when you don't own the mice):

G403: nothing to report
G502:

there is a missing "sniper button" below the 2 left thumb buttons (see https://github.com/libratbag/libratbag/blob/master/data/logitech-g502.svg button 5)
the button between the wheel and the one in the middle (button 8) doesn't report anything, it's a mechanical switch
the wheel has both vertical and horizontal scrolling capabilities, horizontal "buttons" can be configured (but not the vertical ones)


G700:

there are 2 missing "thumb buttons" below the 2 left thumb buttons (see https://github.com/libratbag/libratbag/blob/master/data/logitech-g700.svg button 3 4 5 and 6)
the button between the wheel and the one in the middle (button 10) doesn't report anything, it's a mechanical switch
the wheel has both vertical and horizontal scrolling capabilities, horizontal "buttons" can be configured (but not the vertical ones)
there is no LED on the mouse



Both the G502 and G700 have their button leaders on each side, so I guess this requirement should go away, or we should add a "preferably" in front of the paragraph.

@bentiss Are you aware of any devices that do not have a static button assigned to switching resolutions? With "static" I mean that it's not exposed to the outside and hence libratbag cannot remap it, as on e.g. the G403 and G500.
This is relevant for fa8194a. For Piper's resolutions page, I need to highlight which button(s) is(are) assigned to switch resolutions. For the G403 and G500 this is, as mentioned, not exposed through libratbag and hence we have to set this statically in the SVG. Of course, this will fail to work for devices where this is remappable, if there are any?

column21:
@bentiss Are you aware of any devices that do not have a static button assigned to switching resolutions? With "static" I mean that it's not exposed to the outside and hence libratbag cannot remap it, as on e.g. the G403 and G500.

After reading this, I believe you might be mixing up the mice models and buttons:

the G700, G900 and the G502 in this PR have all a mechanical switch below the wheel that enable/disable the ratchet mode on the wheel. When ratchet is disabled, the wheel is in the "free wheel" mode, where it just doesn't have any click (and a lot of inertia).
all buttons on the Logitech devices I have are addressable and can be remapped in libratbag.

So IMO, the ratchet mode buttons that are just mechanical should just be grayed out in the SVG and nothing should mention it.
Also, there is one thing we need to do on the SVG (no need to ask jimmac for that), is that all the Logitech devices can't remap the vertical wheel events. So there are a couple of leaders/buttons on the drawings that need to be removed (and we need to rearrange the other leaders).

I made an attempt at a G500/G500s SVG copying the G700 style. I have a few remarks regarding the instructions:

There is no size for the image but margins and spacing are given in pixels. Different images will be scaled differently resulting in different margins, spacing, border size, ...
The two main buttons on the G500 and G700 do not have separate pieces, so there is no corresponding object. Mouse wheel tilt is not drawn either. Is the "buttonX" id mandatory for every button? What should be done for this kind of buttons.

Regarding the G500, I have drawn the LEDs but not the leaders. These LEDs cannot be configured with effects, but they can be switched on and off depending on the resolution (and profile). Should they be ignored, or should there be 4 LED leaders?

column21:
I made an attempt at a G500/G500s SVG copying the G700 style. I have a few remarks regarding the instructions:

Looks good!


There is no size for the image but margins and spacing are given in pixels. Different images will be scaled differently resulting in different margins, spacing, border size, ...


Right, good point. Up until now we haven't cared about size too much, since it's unlikely that a user will have two devices to notice the window resizing when (s)he switches device in Piper. Let's add a minimum of 400*400 and a maximum of 500*500.


The two main buttons on the G500 and G700 do not have separate pieces, so there is no corresponding object. Mouse wheel tilt is not drawn either. Is the "buttonX" id mandatory for every button? What should be done for this kind of buttons.


Mouse wheel tilt should be drawn in the latest G502 and G700; it's the little arrows pointing left and right. Copy those and place the marker squares somewhere close to it, and give the arrows the button ids.
The button id is mandatory insofar that without it, the button cannot be highlighted (like this). I agree with @whot in that you can just create an object that overlaps with part of the button (e.g. the top) so it's clear what element is being configured. This also has to be done for the G700 SVG still.

Do note that the G700 still has no buttons in the SVG for button0 and button1 (my Inkscape isn't good enough to fix that)

column20:
During a discussion I had with Jakub Steiner he suggested we use toned-down device SVGs instead. Both @whot and I like this approach, so let's discuss this with the rest! This is a first device he did for us, which is the G403 that I own so I can use it while working on Piper.
The mockups aren't entirely up-to-date (will fix that tonight or tomorrow, most likely) but this is where we're going (that's still proof of concept code that I'll extend in the next few days). As you can see, we will need to retrieve some coordinates from the SVG to place the labels. This is why I also updated the guidelines. I also made the canvas size smaller (simply took what Jakub gave me, it looks good) which noticeably increases performance when opening and resizing Piper.

column21:
That build failure is caused by a missing libsystemd-devel that is now required because ratbagd relies on it. We can't really fix that, semaphore only provides Ubuntu 14.04 and that doesn't have systemd or the version we need. Only option would be to build systemd from scratch but that's bound to have a bunch of other dependency issues.
Might be time to ditch semaphore and find something newer.

column20:
Semaphore CI is still using Ubuntu 14.04, and the shipped systemd version is just too old.
OTOH, Circle CI 2.0 (still beta as of today) allows to use any docker image as a base for running the tests. Meaning that we can have a fedora rawhide image as a base and we do not have to handle the update of systemd meson and others.
Ship a basic circle.yml for Circle CI to run our tests and add the badge in the README.
In the future, this could also allow us to add other distribution as base, so we could run and fix the tests on those other distributions.

column13: meson: hack around Fedora's systemd libdir confusion
column20:
Fedora uses /usr/lib64 as libdir but systemd uses /usr/lib for its files. We
used libdir to install the unit files, which then end up in
/usr/lib64/systemd/systemd where it will be ignored. There's no good way to
avoid this beyond detecting lib64 for this use-case and hacking around it.
#188
Signed-off-by: Peter Hutterer peter.hutterer@who-t.net
column21:

column13: enhance circle.yml with workflows and parallel tests
column20:
Circle CI uses docker, so nothing prevents us from running several tests in parallel for different distributions. Ideally, we should also be able to test the install and be sure we can talk to ratbagd with the dbus activation on those various distributions.
This version runs both Fedora rawhide and Ubuntu 17.04 at the same time.

resolution.

column20:
Two new DBus interfaces:
org.freedesktop.ratbagd1.Manager.Themes -> string array
org.freedesktop.ratbagd1.Device.GetSvg('theme') -> string
The Themes property is a static list of available themes. These are currently
hardcoded in ratbagd, but the theme 'default' is guaranteed to exist.
The GetSvg() method takes a theme name and returns the full file path to the
themed SVG.
Longer-term this will deprecate the Svg and SvgPath properties in the Device
but for now we leave them there.
#204
Signed-off-by: Peter Hutterer peter.hutterer@who-t.net

column13: data: add toned-down SVG for Logitech G500/G500s
column20:
Still WIP, do not merge yet. But I open the pull request for discussion.
The text-align properties are not set on the leaders. I did not find how to add that on rectangles in Inkscape.
I named the layers but that set the inkscape:label attribute not the id one. I guess the id is needed although the readme is not clear about that.
For the main buttons, I added open paths (copied from the light gray area) so there is no border on the bottom. The buttons should be there although not visible.
Since the G500 and the G500s are exactly the same when removing details. They should use the same file. Because of the themes I cannot set the same svg file from the hwdb, so I added a symlink. What is the preferred way to achieve that? meson installs a copy of the file instead of the symlink.
@Hjdskes, I wanted to test your version of piper, but the ledsandbuttons branch is broken, because of lack of theme support, I guess. The ratbagd-themes branch does not seem to work (crashes with bAttributeError: 'RatbagdDevice' object has no attribute 'svg_path').
column21:
Still WIP, do not merge yet. But I open the pull request for discussion.

I named the layers but that set the inkscape:label attribute not the id one. I guess the id is needed although the readme is not clear about that.
For the main buttons, I added open paths (copied from the light gray area) so there is no border on the bottom. The buttons should be there although not visible.
Since the G500 and the G500s are exactly the same when removing details. They should use the same file. Because of the themes I cannot set the same svg file from the hwdb, so I added a symlink. What is the preferred way to achieve that? meson installs a copy of the file instead of the symlink.
@Hjdskes, I wanted to test your version of piper, but the ledsandbuttons branch is broken, because of lack of theme support, I guess. The ratbagd-themes branch does not seem to work (crashes with bAttributeError: 'RatbagdDevice' object has no attribute 'svg_path').

column21:
Oke, back at my laptop now so I can give a proper response. It looks great! Here's a picture:

A few things I noticed:

The arrows next to the scroll wheel that indicate tilting are not recognized as buttons. Please treat the arrows as buttons, with the identifier and paths and everything.
There seem to be two buttons to the left of button 1, but they aren't mapped to anything in Piper (see the screenshot). Is this intentional or an oversight?


The text-align properties are not set on the leaders. I did not find how to add that on rectangles in Inkscape.

This is already mentioned but indeed the SVG editor is the best approach here. I'll update the requirements so that they mention this Monday.

I named the layers but that set the inkscape:label attribute not the id one. I guess the id is needed although the readme is not clear about that.

Good point; I'll ammend the README.

For the main buttons, I added open paths (copied from the light gray area) so there is no border on the bottom. The buttons should be there although not visible.

Excellent solution, I really like how it looks (see screenshot in this comment). Is this something you can also fix for the already merged logitech-g700?

Since the G500 and the G500s are exactly the same when removing details. They should use the same file. Because of the themes I cannot set the same svg file from the hwdb, so I added a symlink. What is the preferred way to achieve that? meson installs a copy of the file instead of the symlink.

This is something for @whot or @bentiss to answer, but I suppose a copy isn't too bad since it's a small file.

column20:
Partially fixes issue #124.
Remapped buttons were diverted at the same time, resulting in a disabled button (diverted buttons don't send their remapped event).
This fixes both remapping the button and changing the divert state correctly.

column20:
Well, there are still a few FIXMEs here and there, but better sending this one out before it gets too much of a beast.
The idea is to instantiate a driver-test libratbag element, and playing with unit tests to see if we messed up the parsing of rabtagctl.
This gives a good idea if ratbagctl/ratbagd works as expected.
The current test run takes roughly 21 seconds on my machine, most of the time is spent by forking, initializing the bus, and settings the devices, etc...
I have a local version that creates only one dbus connection and directly calls the parsing/function from ratbagctl. This version runs in less than a second but fails because ratbagctl python binding doesn't listen for signals and can't update its internal state. I tried playing with the GLib.MainLoop, without success.

column20:
ratbagd_device_new() increments the ref count on the ratbag device, but forgets to unref it in case of an error.
Instead of doing that, just steal the reference (i.e. do nothing), and let the caller unref the device only when an error occurs.

column21: The only failure path in there now calls ratbagd_device_free and that unrefs the lib device. So we behave correctly now - on success we have a valid ref in in the struct, on failure we remove that ref before returning.

Just to be sure I am understanding correctly how cleanup works. In the current code (without your PR), when the function exits, we free the pointer no matter what?

column20:
ratbagd_device_new() increments the ref count on the ratbag device, but forgets to unref it in case of an error.
Instead of doing that, just steal the reference (i.e. do nothing), and let the caller unref the device only when an error occurs.
column21: cleanup inserts the code when the variable goes out of scope (e.g. when returning from the function). It's unconditional, that's why we have to set device to NULL before we return to make sure we don't clean it up on return. You can't return a variable that's marked cleanup either because it will be freed and the return value is invalid.

column13: ratbagd: drop caching of libratbag variables
column20:
Instead of copying them into our own struct, just query libratbag when we need
them. This brings the resolution code in line with the button and LED code
which don't do caching either.
Eventually we may want to cache them again to detect changes behind your
back (if libratbag value != our cached value) but for now this reduces the
work ratbagd does.
Signed-off-by: Peter Hutterer peter.hutterer@who-t.net

column13: RatbagdLed: emit DefaultResolutionChanged on the resolution's object path
column20:
See libratbag/piper#36 (comment)
The only issue now is that the signal is only emitted on the resolution that has just been set the default. At the very least it should also be emitted on the resolution that was the default, but I don't think this is currently possible so we'll have to go with emitting it on all resolutions. What's the best way to go about this?
(We should probably do this for other signals too.)

column21:
I merged this because it matches the current spec. But I think we simply need to move these two signals up into the profile.
Or we have a boolean property of "IsDefault" that changes, that way we get to use the PropertyChanged signals as they happen anyway, without the need for extra signals on our behalf. Certainly easier to implement in ratbagd and means we send only two signals whenever the resolution changes (active off and active on). But it means slightly more work on the callers, they now have to listen to all property changed signals and filter.
I don't know, this is probably something we have to implement one way and see if it makes sense, sorry.

column13: RatbagdLed: emit DefaultResolutionChanged on the resolution's object path
column20:
See libratbag/piper#36 (comment)
The only issue now is that the signal is only emitted on the resolution that has just been set the default. At the very least it should also be emitted on the resolution that was the default, but I don't think this is currently possible so we'll have to go with emitting it on all resolutions. What's the best way to go about this?
(We should probably do this for other signals too.)
column21:
I'm not sure which approach I like best.
The latter would mean that each class in Piper that has a Ratbagd* instance (let's say a RatbagdResolution in this example) needs to connect to that instance's notify::is-default signal that is emitted whenever this property changes (automatically, by GObject). This is straightforward, but I'm not sure how well it will work with profile switches.
The former would mean that each class in Piper that has a Ratbagd* instance needs a reference to a profile, so that it can connect to the profile's default-resolution-changed signal (again, just taking the RatbagdResolution example here) and do the work from that callback. This will likely work better with profile switches, albeit being a little less straightforward.
I'm not yet sure which of these will work best once I will implement profile switching: there won't be just one profile to work with but all of them, and the active one can change at any given time. In this case, it is likely that every class in Piper needs a reference to a profile anyway, which will change depending on the active-profile-changed signal emitted from RatbagdDevice (currently RatbagdProfile, but this will have to be changed to prevent the same issue we're having now with RatbagdResolution) to grab, for example, the new profile's resolution to update.
Maybe we should postpone this until I get to implementing profiles so I can experiment a bit and see which approach is best.

column21: that first commit (add missing Commit()) shows a slight problem we have with ratbagd. ratbagd returns the state of the device before the commit, so in the extreme case we can have a client change that state but never commits it to the device. The next client will then get a state that does not reflect the device. I wonder if we can do client tracking in ratbagd to reset the device on client disconnect.

column20:

column21:
that first commit (add missing Commit()) shows a slight problem we have with ratbagd. ratbagd returns the state of the device before the commit, so in the extreme case we can have a client change that state but never commits it to the device. The next client will then get a state that does not reflect the device. I wonder if we can do client tracking in ratbagd to reset the device on client disconnect.

Nah. I think we should consider the daemon state as being the correct one. If a client forgets to call commit(), we should not have a different state for other clients. This will be race prone and we might end up having too much code for no benefit.
Anyway, if one client forgets to commit, the next one will more likely commit given that we expect clients to actually change the device.

column20:
This is on top of #241 and should only be merged when that one is merged.
When I started tidying up the DBusInterface.md document I noticed a fair few inconsistencies with the API. A few basically superfluous calls and some imbalanced property handling (having a 'foo' readonly property but a SetFoo() method - instead we can just make the property read-write).
Note that his is not complete but I'm about to head out for GUADEC, so better to get this in now. The bits missing are changing the Button interface from using strings to using the libratbag enums and the LED type string to an enum too.
ratbagd.py will need to be synced to piper after merging this but no client changes are needed, this is all handled within the bindings.

column13: Add support for macros in ratbagd
column20:
Disclaimer: I just finished this and I'm running out of time before leaving. The test suite passes, but there may be bugs left, sorry.
Main item here is support for macros in ratbagd. I'm not 100% sure whether that'll be the final API, but the approach here is an array of tuples of (type, value) for each element in the macro. Macro names are picked by ratbagd. There's the theoretical case of exposing macros as separate objects on dbus but I don't think that's worth doing. DBus would allow for SetMacro(s, a(uu)) where we can set the string as well, may be worth doing, maybe not.
Meanwhile, this will be at least useful, if it works ;)
This pull also removes the remaining string button properties and changes them to enums. The LED type is still left and should be fixed too.

column13: ratbagd.c: unlink before emitting property changed
column20: If we emit the changes before unlinking the device, the list of devices hasn't actually changed yet and Piper cannot figure out which devices have been removed. Hence, we simply unlink the device before emitting the signal and all is good again.
column21: If we emit the changes before unlinking the device, the list of devices hasn't actually changed yet and Piper cannot figure out which devices have been removed. Hence, we simply unlink the device before emitting the signal and all is good again.

column13: RatbagdResolution: emit properties changed from signal callbacks
column20:
This allows clients to respond to changes in the active resolution. It's not the cleanest approach, but it works. To clean it up, we could cache the changed resolutions and make sure to only emit the signal on those, just as the FIXME already notes.
References libratbag/piper#132.

column20:
libratbag was printing ERR_INVALID_ADDRESS when it should have been ERR_INVALID_ARGUMENT (a detail from issue #280). This should fix some misleading error messages.
I have left the HID++1.0 error codes in hidpp-generic since they are used in hidpp20.c (for checking the protocol version), but the HID++2.0 error codes could be moved in hidpp20.h if you prefer.
I also extended the string arrays because the value 0xFF was previously excluded but not checked before accessing the array.

Oke I give up on the other failures; I should start writing my GSoC report.

First issue I found is with the IsActive handling in the profile. The test selects a profile which sends SetActive. That triggers the cached dbus property update but does not unset IsActive on the currently active profile. When we then run the test we expect profile 2 to be active, but profile 0 is active too and because we search in order we find 0 first. That triggers the test failures because button mappings are different between the profiles.
This is when running
sudo ./build/ratbagctl.test TestRatbgagCtlButton.test_button_n_action_set_button, I suspect all other tests have a variant of this issue too.
To fix this we'd have to trigger the main loop and wait for the dbus signal to arrive. No idea how this can be done in the test suite.

That'd make sense, yea. Two ways to fix this:

Make ratbagctl work using the main loop, somehow, or
Diverge the bindings between ratbagctl and Piper. This isn't as far-fetched as it sounds as the bindings are really written for Piper with GObject properties and signals and so forth, so you can simplify a lot by making them diverge.

Make ratbagctl work using the main loop, somehow, or
Diverge the bindings between ratbagctl and Piper. This isn't as far-fetched as it sounds as the bindings are really written for Piper with GObject properties and signals and so forth, so you can simplify a lot by making them diverge.

if you spawn ratbagd in a subprocess things magically start working.

That's not quite right here: you're spawning ratbagctl as subprocess, ratbagd is always a subprocess.This means if you have 5 commands in a test, you spawn it 5 times (see: CPU usage). Each instance will get the updated values from ratbagd correctly because there's no buffering. but that's also where the slowdown comes from.

-                stdout.decode('ascii').rstrip('\n'),
-                stderr.decode('ascii').rstrip('\n'))
+                stdout.decode('utf-8').rstrip('\n'),
+                stderr.decode('utf-8').rstrip('\n'))
 
     @classmethod
     def run_ratbagctl_fast(cls, params):
@@ -74,6 +74,7 @@ class TestRatbagCtl(unittest.TestCase):
         error = sys.stderr.getvalue()
         sys.stdout = stdout
         sys.stderr = stderr
+        toolbox.sync_dbus()
         return returncode, output.rstrip('\n'), error.rstrip('\n')
 
     @classmethod

+
 # various constants

@@ -98,6 +100,13 @@ def terminate_ratbagd(ratbagd):
         ratbagd.kill()
     os.unlink(DBUS_CONF_PATH)
 
+
+def sync_dbus():
+    main_context = GLib.MainContext.default()
+    while main_context.pending():
+        main_context.iteration(False)
+
+
 ratbagctl = import_non_standard_path(RATBAGCTL_NAME, RATBAGCTL_PATH)

@@ -111,5 +120,6 @@ __all__ = [
     start_ratbagd,

     open_ratbagd,
+    sync_dbus,
     get_parser,
 ]
This allows to get the dbus signals when properties are changed.
I then tried to make TestRatbagCtlProfile test working (it fails at set active profile). It's a requirement for this to pass before other tests are run.
So, I realized we have an issue in ratbagd in the way we update the profiles on set_active():
diff --git a/ratbagd/ratbagd-profile.c b/ratbagd/ratbagd-profile.c
index 40cbd13..cf767c7 100644
--- a/ratbagd/ratbagd-profile.c
+++ b/ratbagd/ratbagd-profile.c
@@ -294,12 +294,15 @@ static int ratbagd_profile_set_active(sd_bus_message *m,
        if (r < 0)
                return r;
 
+       r = ratbag_profile_set_active(profile->lib_profile);
+       if (r < 0)
+               return r;
+
        ratbagd_for_each_profile_signal(sd_bus_message_get_bus(m),
                                        profile->device,
                                        ratbagd_profile_active_signal_cb);
 
-        return sd_bus_reply_method_return(m, "u",
-                                          ratbag_profile_set_active(profile->lib_profile));
+        return sd_bus_reply_method_return(m, "u", 0);
 }
 
 static int
We should update the values before sending the events that they are changed.
And finally, I think the ratbagd.py binding is messing up somewhere as there are no g-object event raised that I can find on property changed on profile set_active, meaning that we are basically never in a situation where the test suite will work.
Just to be clear, with the bindings from this PR, you can see than setting a profile active doesn't deactivate the previous one, leading to a list of _profiles[] where 2 profiles are active.
Just my 2 cents to help on the bug.
I've pushed the fix for the ratbagd_profile_set_active() to master as 432d32b

column20:
Defer the actual commit so we can return immediately. This fixes the various
timeout issues we've seen on some devices where a commit can take several
seconds.
This commit merely adds the async hook. If the commit itself fails we
should re-sync from libratbag and update all the properties. This is currently
missing.
Fixes #269
Note: this does NOT include the ratbagd.py changes because we currently have some issues with syncing that from piper (see #295). There's a piper-commit pending for adding it there, it will be synced back once that's merged.

Damned, I put a comment in issue #269, but it looks like my firefox screwed up.
I don't think we need that, for the simple reason that it is a client side issue IMO. The problem lies in the fact that piper is always using proxy.call_sync() while here, for commit() it should use the proxy.call() which is async. You'll get the benefit of both this PR and the next one (libratbag/piper#158) without having to touch ratbagd.
Nacking for now to prevent anybody else to ack and merge this.

column20:
Since valgrind is only used for tests it can made an optional dependency if no tests are going to be run. i.e. when it is being installed.
See https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/piper/ and https://aur.archlinux.org/packages/libratbag/ for examples of users who have reported issues.

column20:
This SVG is generic enough to cover 7-button mice with up to 3 LEDs that are
supported but don't have an SVG. The SVG style is intentionally NOT a generic
mouse to make it obvious that something isn't right here. If we use a generic
mouse, people may not put the effort into a proper SVG style because the
generic mouse is good enough.
The fallback is currently only used for test devices

column21: ask for forgiveness, not for permission. so I'm merging this now :)
Also, how do you decide whether to log a warning or an error with success = False? A missing leader should be an error because without it, Piper cannot lay out the widgets.

You can find commits implementing bullets 1 and 2 in my branch: https://github.com/Hjdskes/libratbag/commits/whot-wip/svg-parsing-tool. I've also fixed the G502 with a style property and missing button id, and made a missing leader an error instead.
That leaves bullet 3, which admittedly isn't that important because Piper will still function without it. I also noticed that the script outputs errors for the roccat-kone-xtd's wheel tilt buttons, because they're missing their leaders.

, how do you decide whether to log a warning or an error

something that looks wrong but where we can't be sure is a warning. something that's definitely wrong is an error.

A missing leader should be an error because without it

how are we doing this for the wheel tilt buttons?
@Hjdskes I merged your patches and addressed the comments I had regarding the 502. This won't pass the check suite, we need to figure out what we do for the leader lines on wheel tilt buttons

how are we doing this for the wheel tilt buttons?

Wheel tilt buttons require these elements just as any other button does. I've force pushed to my branch (78f72c4), making sure not to include detritus this time (though there are some thing I'm not sure are required, feel free to remove those if they aren't) and putting it before the commit that introduces the script.
@Hjdskes  thanks, cherry-picked from your branch, reshuffled a few things. ended up squashing all the commits regarding the check-svg.py into one - no need to have more than one here.

column13: Drop key modifiers from action type Key
column20:
Originally I thought we could transparently wrap this in macros inside libratbag, but that's a bit more work. So meanwhile, let's just drop the modifiers so we're at least a step closer to sanity.
I'm not 100% sure anymore whether we should really map this to macros, it seems that the keys have quite a fair bit of limitation (i.e. what key can be mapped) which macros don't have, so maybe keeping it separate is better here.

column21:
If I understand this correctly, this now means that a physical button can be mapped to a single key press (and release)? I'm not sure how useful that is, and this use-case certainly can be captured my a simple macro as well. Perhaps, in that case, we should remove it altogether and only offer macros; are there any devices that do not support macros but do support key presses?
In any case, you should drop 40c0d2f and update tools/ratbagd.py as well. The rest of the changes look good to me.
(Also, how are we doing on dropping ratbag-command? Just wondering since you're now basically required to update a deprecated utility.)

column13: Drop key modifiers from action type Key
column20:
Originally I thought we could transparently wrap this in macros inside libratbag, but that's a bit more work. So meanwhile, let's just drop the modifiers so we're at least a step closer to sanity.
I'm not 100% sure anymore whether we should really map this to macros, it seems that the keys have quite a fair bit of limitation (i.e. what key can be mapped) which macros don't have, so maybe keeping it separate is better here.
column21:
I am not a big fan of this PR either. I think the plan was to remove it all together and let the drivers handle the transformation between macro and key event.

are there any devices that do not support macros but do support key presses?

There are. Any Logitech non gaming device that support redirecting can do that (theoretically). Some, however require the redirection to be handled in software, so we can put whatever we want (and emulate macros).

(Also, how are we doing on dropping ratbag-command? Just wondering since you're now basically required to update a deprecated utility.)

For users, ratbag-command is deprecated, yes. For developers, it's still have interesting features that rabtagctl.devel doesn't. For instance, looking at the raw events from/to the device is much easier with ratbag-command. Also, using gdb with ratbag-command is easier. We talked about it at GUADEC with @whot, but I'd rather be certain that ratbag-command is not useful to anybody before ditching it.

Initially I thought both ratbagctl and .devel where affected, but it turns out we are just trying to kill ratbagd too soon in ratbagctl.devel. This appeared when we switched to async commits in ratbagd.py.
Adding also a commit that fixes permissions for rabtagctl on my setup (Fedora 26).

column20:
Piper is warning that no active resolution is set. This fixes that. We can read the active profile and resolution from report 0xF0.
For the active profile we read the active resolution
from the mouse during probe.
When changing the active profile we set the default
resolution to active.

nothing can actually start using it.

column20:
Fixes both #280 and #122 (hopefully).
This is the first step required before we are finally able to write macros on the device.
The "new" memory API only allows full sectors to be read/written. This ensures we always write the crc and check for it.
Also, now we better detect if the device is using factory profiles or not (see #280).
I still haven't yet implemented caching for the memory. This will be required for macros and to speed up a little bit the parsing of the device.
Please test!
Note: I also quickly wrote a tool to reset the memory to 0x00. This is hopefully the factory default (can't remember if this is true or not).

This new memory model works fine with the G900 as far as I can tell.
There are still a few problems though:

It doesn't handle sector sizes that are not multiple of 16 (as the G603 has)
It fails to commit changes for the G502 as mentionned in #280

I have a fix in the works for the first of these, and I can see what's the problem exactly with the G502 next week.

The bug in #280 is that the firmware sees that the dictionary is invalid (error 02), which is true because we used to write all profiles as disabled. Now, at least locally, the dictionary should be a rewrite of the ROM one, in which all 3 profiles are enabled.

column13: Fix ratbagd return values in dbus methods
column20:
As discussed in #316. For now I went with @whot's suggestion of assertions, but we can easily change this to @bentiss' suggestion to instead emit a signal over DBus indicating an error before trying to commit and then being notified of failures.
There's also a bunch of FIXMEs where I think we could clamp values instead of returning; this might not be necessary for @bentiss' suggestion but I think it's good to do if we stick with the current approach.
column21:
As discussed in #316. For now I went with @whot's suggestion of assertions, but we can easily change this to @bentiss' suggestion to instead emit a signal over DBus indicating an error before trying to commit and then being notified of failures.
There's also a bunch of FIXMEs where I think we could clamp values instead of returning; this might not be necessary for @bentiss' suggestion but I think it's good to do if we stick with the current approach.

column13: Fix ratbagd return values in dbus methods
column20:
As discussed in #316. For now I went with @whot's suggestion of assertions, but we can easily change this to @bentiss' suggestion to instead emit a signal over DBus indicating an error before trying to commit and then being notified of failures.
There's also a bunch of FIXMEs where I think we could clamp values instead of returning; this might not be necessary for @bentiss' suggestion but I think it's good to do if we stick with the current approach.
column21:
Ah, got both your comments in #316 now. I think the new approach is what you're after.

I think we should not assert on libratbag errors, but only for dbus like errors, which we already don't check as a matter of fact.

We do check for dbus errors, and return those error values over the bus. Internal (ratbag) errors are now not returned; we always return success and emit the Resync signal on the device in case of errors.
I wasn't sure if I should unref the device where I added it to the structs, as I'm not explicitly ref'ing it anywhere.
Also, this PR currently only changes those functions where we'd return r upon error. It does not, for example, check for errors in ratbagd-led where we didn't do that before either. I can add this if required.

column20:
The feature discovery code is bugged for HID++2.0. The feature set count does not include the root feature.
This would result in the last feature not being correctly discovered by libratbag.

column13: Generate a direct python wrapper around libratbag with swig
column20:
This is an attempt to fix #274
The idea is to wrap libratbag in python through swig, and make ratbagctl use this wrapper.
It seems to be working fine, and will allow to remove ratbag-command (pure C) in favor of this.
Benefits are that we bypass ratbagd, meaning we can attach gdb or run valgrind on the tools themselves.
Problem is the python wrapper doesn't clean up after itself, and so running valgrind is moot, so further work is required.

column21:
Just a note on the C to python wrapper.
I tried to look at some of them and found out:

manual wrapping -> no point in adding manual code for testing changes (and cumbersome)
SWIG -> automatically generates the wrapper, we just need to write the python replacement for ratbagd.py. The wrapper statically compiles libratbag, so we can keep our code as is.
ctypes -> needs to load a .so. So basically, we need to re-export the .so except we won't install it. It didn't seem right, but if this allows to not pull in too much deps at compile time, I'd agree to look into it a little bit more
cython / pyrex -> most of the wrapper needs to be done by hand, which I do not want to do, because: what's the point?

column13: Generate a direct python wrapper around libratbag with swig
column20:
This is an attempt to fix #274
The idea is to wrap libratbag in python through swig, and make ratbagctl use this wrapper.
It seems to be working fine, and will allow to remove ratbag-command (pure C) in favor of this.
Benefits are that we bypass ratbagd, meaning we can attach gdb or run valgrind on the tools themselves.
Problem is the python wrapper doesn't clean up after itself, and so running valgrind is moot, so further work is required.
column21:
So the purpose here is to replace ratbag-command.c with an automatically generated version, using ratbagc.py, right? I suppose that removes the current ratbag-command.c, but what will happen to ratbagctl and ratbagctl.test?
Unless you'll deprecate ratbagctl in favor of this new ratbag-command, we'll have two "user interfaces" to maintain, both using similar but slightly different bindings (ratbagd.py and ratbagc.py). I don't think this is where we should want to go. I understand the need for having a tool that you can use to debug with, but in my opinion if we go through with this we should merge ratbagctl into ratbag-command.c.

column13: Generate a direct python wrapper around libratbag with swig

column21:
So the purpose here is to replace ratbag-command.c with an automatically generated version, using ratbagc.py, right?

Correct

I suppose that removes the current ratbag-command.c,

Yes, it will eventually disappear

but what will happen to ratbagctl and ratbagctl.test?

ratbagctl is the tool that we will ship, it doesn't require root.
ratbagctl.test could be split in one that checks for the libratbag bindings, and one for the dbus bindings. This is beneficial to have a tool that allows to remove the man in the middle.

Unless you'll deprecate ratbagctl in favor of this new ratbag-command, we'll have two "user interfaces" to maintain,

We already have ratbagctl and ratbag-command. And we can not ship this ratbag-command.py for the simple reason that it requires root. So ratbagctl is not soon to be deprecated.

both using similar but slightly different bindings (ratbagd.py and ratbagc.py). I don't think this is where we should want to go. I understand the need for having a tool that you can use to debug with, but in my opinion if we go through with this we should merge ratbagctl into ratbag-command.c.

The problem with ratbagctl with ratbagd is that it gets tricky to attach a debugger to it and to run valgrind because we fork the ratbagd process. And we want to attach the tools on ratbagd, not on the python dbus client. IIRC, @whot tried to circumvent that during GUADEC, and it almost worked until it was finally not possible to do it. This is why we created bug #274.
From your perspective I understand you do not see the point of this "new" ratbag-command. But when we are writing the drivers and debugging them, it gets critical to be able to attach the debugging tools.
Last, the layer in ratbagc.py is just a very mechanical file that allows to match ratbagd.py so we can just swap the two of them. Compared to ratbag-command.c, maintaining a thin wrapper which will be mirrored from ratbagd.py will be much less of a pain than maintaining a full C program that have some very creative way of handling command line arguments.
The main focus will still be on ratbagctl, rest is just developer tools.
Anyway, if there are too much push back for this we can drop it and continue as it is today.

column21:
ctypes -> needs to load a .so. So basically, we need to re-export the .so except we won't install it. It didn't seem right, but if this allows to not pull in too much deps at compile time, I'd agree to look into it a little bit more

should be possible to build a libratbag.so but use install: false and use it solely for the ctypes conversion. And as long as you don't declare_dependency() with it and then add it to the deps, nothing will use it. Since we don't care about sonames etc, we can just do a regex symbol export to avoid leaking the world. Whatever causes us to write the least manual code is what gets my vote :)

column13: Generate a direct python wrapper around libratbag with swig
column20:
This is an attempt to fix #274
The idea is to wrap libratbag in python through swig, and make ratbagctl use this wrapper.
It seems to be working fine, and will allow to remove ratbag-command (pure C) in favor of this.

column21:
should be possible to build a libratbag.so but use install: false and use it solely for the ctypes conversion. And as long as you don't declare_dependency() with it and then add it to the deps, nothing will use it. Since we don't care about sonames etc, we can just do a regex symbol export to avoid leaking the world. Whatever causes us to write the least manual code is what gets my vote :)

Actually, I tried this (more or less) yesterday. It is indeed easy enough to generate the .so without requiring the SWIG dependency. The problem lies that once the .so is there, we can hook up to it, but we need to manually declare the types for the conversion between C to Python. Or when we fetch a string, it'll give us the pointer value instead of the actual string.
So we are basically down to the same than cython/pyrex.
Note that there are other automatic wrapper generators which then make use of cython or ctypes. But swig is generally available while those need to be git cloned from some random repo (or tuned down to Qt most of the time).

column21:
Few comments on the PR:

there is no good way to test this currently as ratbag-command and ratbagd/ratbagctl are not updated
which means I have some unsupported -1 on the G900 that makes the info command of ratbagctl crash on the G900
the G502 always seem to say that the modes are off even though the led is light up
trying to set up something on the g502 returns an error saying that setting the LED is not supported here (did you add a new capability?)
when starting ratbagd, the g502 lights off and on again... while for the G900 we just read the state in the profile, so I wonder why you are forced to use software controlled LED...

Regarding the code itself, there are a few formatting issues here and there. We can pinpoint those shortly before merging once it is fully functional.
If the assumption that you exported new capabilities is correct, then this is not something you should do (I think). The LED interface should stay the same whether or not you are using RGB LED. We should however add a new capability/function to query the numbers of bits we can set for the color.
And regarding the split of the patches, add non-RGB led reading  and add non-RGB led updating should come together in the same patch, and I think the last one should also be squashed with the previous too.
Basically, when you split code to have a smaller commit, you always need to ask 2 questions:

is my code not actually adding dead code?
can my code be bisected?

For the first one, you should make sure that any function is actually called and be reachable (from  a rough look, it seem the led reading and led updating commits are not raising a warning by gcc but nothing sets the capability, so basically there is no way to test this code until the last one)
For the second advice, you should always make sure the code is bisectable. Here, a git bisect will say that the faulty commit will be the last one when this one doesn't do much.
So it is fine to have big commits if there is no other way around it.

column13: Non-RGB LEDs support for Logitech mice

column21:
I guess there are a few points that were not totally clear, when I say non-RGB LEDs this actually means monochrome LEDs. There is no way at all to control the LED color through feature 0x1300. The LED just gives you a bitfield which indicates what effects it supports (breathing, blinking, etc...).
Also LEDs advertised through 0x1300 do not always support the full range of effects available, currently this is handled by returning a -ENOTSUP when trying to apply an effect to a LED that does not support it.
I've not added a new ratbag capability, I've only added one to the hidpp20_driver_data structure in order to be able to select the correct method to update the led, either 0x1300 or 0x8070. Though your problem might related to the above.
As for the on and off problem at startup, this is because the code sets the software control property at startup causing the LED control to go from FW to SW and a little flicker. I'll fix this by only turning on software control when writing a LED.
And finally, thanks for the git advices ;)

This adds support for the non-RGB LEDs feature in HID++2.0 mice.
Should fix #325
Feedback and advice on general structure welcome!
column21:
After some extensive tests, it works fine with:

 - G300s
 - G302
 - G502
 - G603
 - G703
 - G900
 - G903

 If anyone has one I haven't tested that would be great!
Nice. Sorry if I do not review this right now.
I am at a conference until the rest of the week and can't really work on libratbag.
If anyone else wants to do the review, feel free to pick it up.

column20:
This is something we'll eventually need when we start monitoring events. We don't have a user for this just yet, so we shouldn't merge it.
I'm sending this as PR now because the code is written and I think that's the approach we want. So once we need it, we can rebase this and push it out.

column13: Add a ratbag_dispatch() method to allow hooking into a mainloop
column20:
This is something we'll eventually need when we start monitoring events. We don't have a user for this just yet, so we shouldn't merge it.
I'm sending this as PR now because the code is written and I think that's the approach we want. So once we need it, we can rebase this and push it out.
column21: any event processing inside libratbag will need it. This is internal API, not external so it's ratbagd that keeps calling into libratbag to process stuff - invisible to the client. Potential users are any driver API that uses e.g. dbus to communicate with some other API (like openrazer)

column20: This fixes writing profiles on the G9. The problem was when setting the current resolution, which is a short report on the G9 but a long on other models. While looking into it I noticed that we are getting/setting the current resolution unnecessarily many times, and that we set it before the profile write which causes the device to jump to its default resolution.
column21: This fixes writing profiles on the G9. The problem was when setting the current resolution, which is a short report on the G9 but a long on other models. While looking into it I noticed that we are getting/setting the current resolution unnecessarily many times, and that we set it before the profile write which causes the device to jump to its default resolution.

CC @lrenaud

column21: for a few special values like monochrome or 1-bit RBG we can't just rely on clamping. piper would still give you a full rbg range and how that is clamped to 1 bit isn't defined (other than 256 == on). So for those cases having the range exposed helps providing the right UI and setting the right value.

column20:
This is a working fix for #380, though I wanted some feedback on design first.

First, I've had to merge liblur into libhidpp in order to talk to the USB receiver during the hidpp20 driver probe phase
Since the SVG is not known until speaking with the receiver, the ratbag_device_data structure needs to be updated during the probe phase or we need to change ratbag's device identification procedure.
This fix avoids making big changes to the general device discovery since this is Logitech-specific at the cost of making the ratbag_device_data structure mutable from outside libratbag-data.c. What do you think is the best way?
Small change to liblur to consider the Logitech gaming mouse USB receiver (046d:c539) as a unifying receiver

Signed-off-by: Ogier Bouvier obouvier@logitech.com

well, there is still a long road to go before this gets in a common distribution. I have scheduled the series for 5.2, but we are at 5.1-rc6 now. So there is at least 2+2+8=12 weeks before 5.2 is out, and then I guess distributions will take at least a couple of weeks before updating.
Also, I'd like to get the powerplay mouse mat handled by the kernel first. Just saying in case somebody has one around :)

column13: Use Sphinx to generate the DBus API documentation
column20: This is just the basic conversion - the Read-the-docs theme allows for a lot more documentation to be added at some later point.
column21:
That seems quite complex :/ I am confident there are no other ways, but still...

There's the breathe extension I just found: https://breathe.readthedocs.io/en/latest/
That may move the doxygen+xml bit to sphinx directly, but in the end we'll do the same thing anyway.

isn't doc/dbus.rst autogenerated? If so, is it relevant to add it to the commit?

No, it's not. That's the handwritten one. The big problem with the dbus API is that it doesn't exist anywhere but on dbus. It's not like a class or something, it really needs to be hand-written.

I think I'd like to have the circle.yml updated to generate the documentation also in the CI, that would help knowing the dependencies and make sure the whole thing compiles

I can do that easily enough, but fwiw I think the documentation generation + upload will be a manual task, once the DBus API changes we'll likely won't have too many changes here. Anyway, let's see how this goes

circleci integration is added now, and I'v pushed the output to gh-pages, so it's already showing up on http://libratbag.github.io/

column13: DBus API change to switch to discrete resolution lists
column20:
This builds on top of #392
Changes from a dpi min/max to a discrete list of "here are the resolutions we support". This makes it easier for clients to do the right thing.

column13: circle.yml: deploy docs when the master branch is updated
column20:
Note that the push requires a specific private key in the libratbag circle CI organization, meaning that only the master branch of libratbag will be allowed to push to the doc repo.
Note also that only the master branch will trigger the request:

any PR will not trigger the request
any push on the master branch of a personal repo will fail while attempting to write the docs, if the repo is setup to use circleCI too.

column13: circleCI: cache DNF data accross jobs
column20:
We don't really need to redownload everything for all the various fedora jobs.
Launch an extra Fedora job that retrieves and store the DNF cache, and then make use of it in the rest of the workflow.
We do not gain much right now in term of time spent. We should get a rough 1 min when deploying the docs though on the master branch.
This goes on top of PR #394.

column13: Initial driver and svg for steelseries rival 310
column20:
This is the initial step towards a driver for the steelseries mice. In the first version this is just for the "rival 310" but the driver should be usable for the other models with minor adjustments in the driver.
The driver does not yet support button mappings or any of the non-solid LED modes. Resolutions, report rate, and solid colors on two LEDs are working.
I open this PR now for two reasons. I would like to include it in the current form. I have found a couple of other developers I would like to attract to the project. And being able to set some but not all available settings is better than nothing I guess :)
The other reason is to discuss some issues with the device. It does not support reading out the current onboard configuration. This is of course bad for the experience in piper. For now the driver just picks some default values during probe that I found sensible What do we do for such a device? One solution could be to store the configuration on disk and load that during probe. Not ideal, but better than a full reset every time. Or should we simply not support devices with such limitations?
One of the LEDs is placed within the scroll wheel. I think we need a new LED TYPE for that. I have seen some of the logitech mice do the same. Is there a reason such a type does not exist yet?

it does not support reading out the current onboard configuration

No specific reason, please add it.

column20:
Next step before supporting full macro write, allow to detect keybindings and translate them as macro.
Currently only onboard profiles in HID++2.0 support writing back them, so we might want to convert everyone before actually merging this (given that we will change the state of the profiles for the other drivers).
Anyway, reading works OK for HID++ 1.0 and 2.0, it would be cool if the other maintainers could give a try at their drivers so we merge it safely.
This goes on top of #401, so only the last 2 patches matter.

column21:
I set two key combinations in LGS on my G300. The device only supports keys, not macros. One button I set to "A" and the other "ctrl+T". In ratbagctl they show as:
Button: 5 type pinkie is mapped to macro '↕RESERVED'
Button: 6 type pinkie2 is mapped to macro '↕RESERVED'
In Piper they show as ↕A and ↕T.

column21:
On my G9 (HID++1.0) I set a macro to ABC.
Ratbagctl correctly sees it as:
Button: 4 type thumb2 is mapped to macro '↓A 1ms ↑A 1ms ↓B 1ms ↑B 1ms ↓C 1ms ↑C'
In Piper I can see the start of the macro on the button. Clicking it to configure goes directly to the list of button options, so I cannot confirm the last part of the macro. But the start looked correct.

column13: use SVGs from the source dir in .devel
column20:
When using ratbagctl.devel we would use the .device files
from the source dir. This patch also makes it use the .svg
files from the source dir. This makes it easier to edit the
svg and less surprising now that it follows the .devices files.
We need to treat the .device and .svg file a bit different. The
reason is that in soure the device files are in a separate dir
'data/devices' but we do not use the 'devices' dir when installed.

column13: Don't install the default theme svgs
column20:
No-one appears to be using these and the efforts to create SVGs
go into the GNOME ones (used by piper). Leave them in the git tree in case
someone wants to pick them up but until we have a consumer it's not worth it
installing them.
Note: this kinda bears the question now whether we should even bother claiming to have a 'default' theme...

why do we need to support the devices if they're clearly not meeting the requirements we have?

The reason is that if you happen to have one of these mouse connected to your system, libratbag (or ratbagd) will fail to start given that the assert will be raised.
An other solution would be to blacklist or whitelist Logitech devices, but this is maybe not something we want. Actually, we could require feature 0x8100 to be present, but given the MX Master can have the DPI changed, I still think we should support it somehow.

column20:
This PR adds support for the oldest and simplest SteelSeries mouse I could find. It only supports setting resolution and report rate. The protocol used in the earlier mice was slightly different than the latest models so I had to put in some if/else for that. The code paths and report ID's seem similar right now but differences will come when I add support for some of the next devices.
As the devices cannot be queried I had to push the device specific data to the .device files.
I added leader lines to the buttons on the SVG even though the buttons are not programmable. I have set the capabilities such that Piper is aware of this and it does not show the leaders (or the buttons page at all).

I added leader lines to the buttons on the SVG even though the buttons are not programmable. I have set the capabilities such that Piper is aware of this and it does not show the leaders (or the buttons page at all).

column13: steelseries: support cycle and breathing LED mode
column20:
To specify the colors to cycle trough we write a list of
colors and their individual share of the total cycle duration.
Solid colors only have a single color in their list.
Breathing mode will cycle to and from the picked color and black.
Cycle mode will cycle through red, green, and blue.

column13: Force at least one profile to be enabled on Logitech mice
column20:
Since the firmware refuses to accept profile dictionnary with all profiles disabled, this enables the first profile in the dictionnary in case all profiles are disabled. This fixes #428 by fixing the case where a mouse is plugged in with all profiles disabled.
Signed-off-by: Ogier Bouvier obouvier@logitech.com

column13: meson/dbus: support build time option to restrict D-Bus access
column20:
This change makes it possible to pass '-Ddbus-group=' to limit
the access to the ratbagd D-Bus service. The default remains to allow
everyone access to the service.
This allows integrators to choose more conservative security settings
e.g. only allowing users in the 'games' group to talk to the ratbagd
daemon.

IMO it's more of a design issue (then piper issue) than a libratbag issue for the moment. For the roccat, IIRC, libratbag exports the number of buttons times the modes (2). So here, I am not so sure what to do with such mode.
@Hjdskes any ideas on how we can present this to userspace (as this might involve changes in libratbag after we make the decision)

column21:
I'm not sure that a side view is going to be particularly easier to read, and if I am not mistaken @jimmac advocated against having multiple angles. Keep in mind that the mouse buttons will be highlighted when hovered. I think for now you can maybe exaggerate a little bit by making the buttons slightly larger than they should be scale-wise, so they are even/a little easier to notice.
As for the shift mode -- I haven't seen that before. I'm not sure how I missed that and why no one mentioned it earlier! I'm thinking that Piper can read when the Shift key is pressed and, when it knows that the current mouse supports this, update its UI to reflect the new state. So to configure e.g. Shift + left mouse button, you would press Shift in Piper and then select the button mapping to the left mouse button.
I think this is the most transparent, as there would be no need for another layer in the SVG or for multiple leader lines and double the amount of buttons in the UI. To make this feature discoverable, the SVGs could have a little arrow or something in some corner that is highlighted when Shift is pressed.

column21:
Here's an implementation of @whot's partial side-view idea:

I'm not sure if that's exactly what you had in mind, but I think it makes the buttons quite a bit more decipherable. For what it's worth, I think it also helps the aesthetic by allowing the main mouse drawing to keep a consistently orthographic projection (when looking at the mouse from straight overhead you only really see the sides of the top buttons; my first version mixed and matched perspectives a bit which stuck out as odd to me after staring at it long enough).

column21:
I've now added leaders to the SVG. In order to try and manage the button overload on the left side, I overlayed the leaders for each "column" of buttons on top of one another. My assumption is that when a button is to be highlighted, its group is brought to the top and the fill/stroke colors changed. If that is indeed what happens, then I think having them overlayed won't be too confusing. Just in case, I also labeled each leader at the button end. Each label is also part of its respective leader group for added highlighting.
The main downside I can see so far is that the overlayed leaders become "thicker" looking than the non overlayed ones, because the partially transparent anti-aliasing pixels at the edges of the leader line add up and become darker than they otherwise would be. I'm not sure how to fix that, but it seems pretty minor.

column21:
My assumption is that when a button is to be highlighted, its group is brought to the top and the fill/stroke colors changed.

The fill/stroke colors of the button are changed and brought to the top (IIRC), but the leader lines are not highlighted nor brought to the top.

The main downside I can see so far is that the overlayed leaders become "thicker" looking than the non overlayed ones, because the partially transparent anti-aliasing pixels at the edges of the leader line add up and become darker than they otherwise would be. I'm not sure how to fix that, but it seems pretty minor.

This can also be considered an advantage because it indicates that there are several overlapped lines there. I don't think this has to be a problem.
Can you test this SVG in Piper @gandalf3?

column20:
The steelseries mice have 2 resolutions. The range/interval
is different per device. We cannot query the devices, so we
have to pick some defaults. Before we took the two first in
the list to be safe. It is a pretty bad default though. Using
800 and 1600 is supported by all known devices and seem as
more reasonable defaults.

column20:
I need to store in the .device file for the steelseries mice whether they support mapping buttons to keys or not. I cannot query it and it the feature does not follow any of the other settings, like DeviceVersion.
The steelseries mice do not support storing real macros on the device itself, only key+modifiers. This can be seen as a single-step macro. Since it seems we will need a global option for macro length anyway I thought that using a macro length of 0 could be used to indicate that no keys can be set.
I have only updated the .device files for the steelseries mice in this PR.
Is it a reasonable option? And is there a better name than MacroLength?
