column21:
@yaneti please check commit b164fa6. It's a while ago and I can't remember the details but presumably I did this for a reason :)
I think the effect of this was being able to have ratbagd.service as a separately-controlled entity from the dbus service (i.e. you could run ratbagd.service without dbus activation too).

column13: dbus service: use the actual ratbagd service name and not the alias
column20: The alias can be used only when the service is enabled
column21:
@whot, So I don't know if older systemd / dbus worked in a different way but here with
systemd-237-1.git78bd769.fc28.x86_64
dbus-1.12.0-1.fc28.x86_64

the change allows dbus activation to actually start the ratbagd.service when its not explicitly enabled. It works that way because unit aliases are only active once the service is enabled. example:
# systemctl status ratbagd.service
● ratbagd.service - Daemon to introspect and modify configurable mice
   Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/system/ratbagd.service; disabled; vendor preset: disabled)
# ratbagctl 
Unable to connect to ratbagd over dbus

log:
Feb 21 01:41:36 d2 dbus-daemon[781]: [system] Activating via systemd: service name='org.freedesktop.ratbag1' unit='dbus-org.freedesktop.ratbag1.service' requested by ':1.779' (uid=0 pid=26954 comm="/usr/bin/python3 /usr/bin/ratbagctl " label="unconfined_u:unconfined_r:unconfined_t:s0-s0:c0.c1023")
Feb 21 01:41:36 d2 dbus-daemon[781]: [system] Activation via systemd failed for unit 'dbus-org.freedesktop.ratbag1.service': Unit dbus-org.freedesktop.ratbag1.service not found.

# systemctl enable ratbagd.service
Created symlink /etc/systemd/system/dbus-org.freedesktop.ratbag1.service → /usr/lib/systemd/system/ratbagd.service.
# systemctl status ratbagd.service 
● ratbagd.service - Daemon to introspect and modify configurable mice
   Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/system/ratbagd.service; enabled; vendor preset: disabled)
   Active: inactive (dead)
# ratbagctl 
event5:    Logitech Gaming Mouse G300

log:
Feb 21 01:41:48 d2 dbus-daemon[781]: [system] Activating via systemd: service name='org.freedesktop.ratbag1' unit='dbus-org.freedesktop.ratbag1.service' requested by ':1.780' (uid=0 pid=26988 comm="/usr/bin/python3 /usr/bin/ratbagctl " label="unconfined_u:unconfined_r:unconfined_t:s0-s0:c0.c1023")
Feb 21 01:41:48 d2 systemd[1]: Starting Daemon to introspect and modify configurable mice...
Feb 21 01:41:48 d2 dbus-daemon[781]: [system] Successfully activated service 'org.freedesktop.ratbag1'
Feb 21 01:41:48 d2 systemd[1]: Started Daemon to introspect and modify configurable mice.

With the proposed change there is no need to explicitly enable the service
# systemctl status ratbagd.service 
● ratbagd.service - Daemon to introspect and modify configurable mice
   Loaded: loaded (/usr/lib/systemd/system/ratbagd.service; disabled; vendor preset: disabled)
   Active: inactive (dead)
# ratbagctl 
event5:    Logitech Gaming Mouse G300      

log:
Feb 21 02:04:11 d2 dbus-daemon[781]: [system] Activating via systemd: service name='org.freedesktop.ratbag1' unit='ratbagd.service' requested by ':1.794' (uid=0 pid=29390 comm="/usr/bin/python3 /usr/bin/ratbagctl " label="unconfined_u:unconfined_r:unconfined_t:s0-s0:c0.c1023")
Feb 21 02:04:11 d2 systemd[1]: Starting Daemon to introspect and modify configurable mice...
Feb 21 02:04:11 d2 dbus-daemon[781]: [system] Successfully activated service 'org.freedesktop.ratbag1'
Feb 21 02:04:11 d2 systemd[1]: Started Daemon to introspect and modify configurable mice.

column20: The alias can be used only when the service is enabled
column21:
the change allows dbus activation to actually start the ratbagd.service when its not explicitly enabled.

but that's the point of the alias, otherwise you cannot ever disable the service because dbus will always start it. With the alias, you have dbus activation but still leave the administrator free to disable the service.

column13: dbus service: use the actual ratbagd service name and not the alias
column20: The alias can be used only when the service is enabled
column21:
Well, I don't quite understand why ratbagd as a service should have to be explicitly enabled or disabled. Basically it should just work whenever one uses ratbagctl,  the desktop does something with the dbus interface  or some udev hook for specific hardware decides to start it.  And it should probably exit by itself if it doesn't find any support devices that it needs to manage
In a pinch disabling it should be done by masking.
Other examples:   org.freedesktop.Accounts , org.freedesktop.GeoClue2, org.freedesktop.fwupd, org.freedesktop.PackageKit..

column20: The alias can be used only when the service is enabled
column21:
Well, I don't quite understand why ratbagd as a service should have to be explicitly enabled or disabled.

we're changing system-wide hardware state. Being able to disable it seemed like a good idea. But reading up on masking now - yeah, that seems like the correct solution over enable/disable.

column13: Helpers for conversion betwen macro and key+modifier binding
column20:
This expands the approach in #402 to also cover modifier keys, and goes for a full conversion to macros instead of converting to/from the key binding action. The drivers can use the functions to convert between a key+modifier bit field and a single key press macro.
The second patch is a conversion of the logitech-g300 driver.

column20:
Adding a short sleep between calls makes the writes to the device more reliable.
I noticed that occasionally the mouse would only pick up some of the changed settings. The official configurator waits 10 ms between each message and 20 ms before the save. Adding these here seems to have made the writes more reliable.

column21: @whot yes, I am already there but thanks anyway. The only person I was able to talk to was bentiss and it still was a bit hard.
I tried to add support in ratbagctl but it's not working right now. You can see here FFY00@eaf30d6.

@whot @bentiss Do we want to support a Trigger mode for LEDs? The LED will light up for a set duration after clicking the configured button/key. I have not seen this feature on any device other than steelseries.

I think the Logitech mice have some advanced trigger mechanism for the macros too, but IIRC, it's only linked to the button that initiates the macro. And now that I think about it, I do not think the macro could control the LEDs.
So my initial thought would be that we should hold off until more devices are supporting this, because we don't know if the API is the correct one based on only one device. For the record, we already removed features in the past because they were only for one particular device/brand, and maintaining too many features is something we do not want to be confronted with.
@bentiss I totally understand. If it helps, I would be happy to maintain this feature.
I am going to close this at it seems the changes won't be merged anytime soon.

column13: remove clang analyzer false positive warnings
column20:
https://bugs.llvm.org/show_bug.cgi?id=3888
clang analyzer doesn't know how to handle __attribute__(cleanup()).
There are only 2 warnings raised because the analyzer only look at the current compilation unit for checking the malloc call. So only those 2 are detected by clang and then marked as memory leak.
This also means our current continuous integration doesn't check for memory leaks.

column20:
This PR implements the Steelseries Sensei Raw. This device has a monochromatic LED which required a new command to be implemented (along with a device property, MonoLed to enable it). It also has a simpler key mapping command (basically no modifiers are allowed), which required tying a number of properties to a single device property (ShortButton).
I'm not sure I've implemented the features in the best way, let me know if there's a better way to do it.
I also had a go at the device image but I'm not sure it turned out great, I'm no artist.

column13: meson: generate pkgconfig file for libratbag

column13: meson: generate pkgconfig file for libratbag
column20: Generate a pkgconfig file so that libratbag can be easily used as a dependency in other projects.
column21: Do we have a specific use-case here? libratbag used to be a library (hence the name) with a separate dbus server (ratbagd). But eventually we found that that architecture doesn't make a lot of sense, you need root access and the only sensible way to abstract that away is a dbus server. ratbagd is generic enough that it can be used by any application, so I'm not sure exposing libratbag as a real library makes much sense.

column13: meson: generate pkgconfig file for libratbag
column20: Generate a pkgconfig file so that libratbag can be easily used as a dependency in other projects.
column21: I see this as the easiest way to ensure libratbag is installed. Right now, piper doesn't check at all if it is installed. Piper gets successfully installed even if libratbag is missing, and it results in errors when trying to run piper. Maybe we don't need to expose the library but we should provide a way to make sure libratbag is installed. Also, providing a pkgconfig file, even without a library (I don't know if that's possible but I assume it is), allows build systems to know the path prefix of the libratbag instalation. This, for example, removes the need for hardcoded path lists in projects using libratbag's assets (svg files, etc.). I don't know if I made myself much clear, it's 4am and I'm on my phone 😁.

column13: meson: generate pkgconfig file for libratbag
column20: Generate a pkgconfig file so that libratbag can be easily used as a dependency in other projects.
column21:
hmm. pkg-config files are usually shipped by the development packages and are only applicable during build time and their primary reason is to sort out CFLAGS and the linker arguments. And we really have no build-time dependency on libratbag and we don't want to expose any of the internal libraries.
I think what you want to do (and a laudable thing it is :) would be better with a find_program() at build-time. If we check for ratbagd to exist, we can at least put a massive warning out.

column21:
Please correct me if I am wrong but we shouldn't hardcode the file name when using it in the code, right? It should be provided by the .device file. If this is correct, I don't see the point of creating a symlink since we can only have one Svg field in the .device file. And in that case, I think it would make more sense to have a file named vendor-device1-device2.svg instead of on named vendor-device1.svg providing the image for both device1 and device2, even though they are essentially the same.
If there's no problem hardcoding the .svg file names, I think this design would make more sense.
.../libratbag/devices/vendor-device1-device2.device
[Device]
Name=Vendor Device1/Device2
Svg=vendor-device1-device2.svg
...

.../libratbag/gnome/
vendor-device1.svg -> vendor-device1-device2.svg
vendor-device2.svg -> vendor-device1-device2.svg
vendor-device1-device2.svg

Maybe I am making a big deal out of nothing but that seems to me like a bad way to handle things.

column20:
Just a quick change to add support for the G102 and G203 mice.
These mice are functionally identical and share a device ID, they only differ in marketing materials and which countries sell each mouse.
column21:
There are two issues at play here. It is my understanding of @Hjdskes's comment that the symlink would be used in place of a proper G203/G102 SVG until one was made.
The second issue, and the one more relevant to your (@FFY00) question is naming of the device/svg file supporting the the G102 and G203 devices. The dual naming convention makes more sense to me as it also avoids potential confusion while we are simultaneously reusing the G303 SVG.

column20:
Just a quick change to add support for the G102 and G203 mice.
These mice are functionally identical and share a device ID, they only differ in marketing materials and which countries sell each mouse.
column21:
We both agree about the naming convention. What I don't understand is the need for symlinks since (I assume) we shouldn't hardcode the .svg names. The .device should be used to figure it them out instead.
EDIT
I definitely misunderstood the situation. I have been a bit anxious about some personal things and I apologise. I am a bit embarrassed. We are all on the same page. My original comment is still relevant.

column20:

column21:
I think using the .device name to resolve the .svg files is a wise route in the long run, but wouldn't that make symlinks necessary regardless? When we add a new .device file we create the .svg file, and if an SVG doesn't exist yet then a symlink to a suitable replacement is put in place until one is made available. The alternate of course is to resolve to the fallback.svg file.
Either way, it sounds like rebuilding the system to resolve .device to .svg is beyond the scope of the current pull request. I've pushed the device file name changes to my branch.

column20:
This is a driver for the logitech G600. The logic is fairly close to that of the G300, but it was easier to start developing it as a separate driver. The result of trying to combine the two drivers was a large
if/else code due to the differences in the report messages and a few differences in the features (LEDs mostly). I will be happy to merge it with the G300 if we do not want to keep them separate.
The driver still has a few bugs when used from Piper. The active resolution is not set when changing profile. And the duration for the LED effect does not have the correct max duration (16000 ms). There are probably more issues as the button setting has only been tested lightly. I am mostly posting it so @gandalf3 can start testing it and do the final adjustments of the SVG in #446
This PR assumes that the .SVG is already present in the data/gnome dir

I can bind a button to the "G Shift" key (second mode), but I don't see a way to set up binds which only fire when second mode is active?

column21: @phomes I see. Regarding the active profile, ratbagctl profile active get returns the profile selected in piper, but doesn't change when the active profile is changed via buttons on the mouse. Also, selecting a profile in piper enables piper's apply button, but updates the profile active on the mouse before the apply button is clicked (possibly a piper issue?).

column20:
This is a driver for the logitech G600. The logic is fairly close to that of the G300, but it was easier to start developing it as a separate driver. The result of trying to combine the two drivers was a large
if/else code due to the differences in the report messages and a few differences in the features (LEDs mostly). I will be happy to merge it with the G300 if we do not want to keep them separate.
The driver still has a few bugs when used from Piper. The active resolution is not set when changing profile. And the duration for the LED effect does not have the correct max duration (16000 ms). There are probably more issues as the button setting has only been tested lightly. I am mostly posting it so @gandalf3 can start testing it and do the final adjustments of the SVG in #446
This PR assumes that the .SVG is already present in the data/gnome dir
column21: Feel free to push the branch once most of the CI succeeds

column20:
This is the initial work on cmstorm based mice, specifically the CMStorm Recon. There are other mice in the CMStorm range, I'm not sure how reusable this driver will be for them.
I still need to do the artwork for this mouse, but I think the rest is complete.
Interestingly this mouse supports placing mouse presses/releases within it's macros, something which I believe isn't supported yet.

column21:
Just got around to reviewing the SVG, and have a few comments.
First, for some leader lines there is too little vertical spacing. Remember that the lines will point to buttons, and there needs to be enough vertical space in between two lines to fit this.
Second, there are two leader lines pointing to the scroll wheel. If this is to indicate that you can move the scroll wheel left/right, please indicate this better with a better placement. The same goes for the buttons in the middle of the mouse: there are two buttons, but three leader lines. There are also two leader lines in the (vertical) center of the mouse that do not seem to point to any buttons.

column21:
Just getting back to this. I think the vertical spacing is fine. What may be confusing matters is that the scroll wheel has 2 leader lines, one for the button, one for the LED. There's also a leader line for the LED on the profile buttons.
I've check the spacing in Piper and none of the buttons overlap each other.

column20:
When looking into why setting macros are not working on the G9 (HID++1-0) I noticed that the G9 svg was missing the wheel left/right buttons, and that thus some buttons were also numbered wrong.
Adds wheel left/right clicks and adjusts button numbering.
(Button5 seems to be configurable in the profile, but no such button
exists on the mouse)

column21:
The tests fail with:
$ ./check-svg.py logitech-g9.svg 
ERROR:logitech-g9.svg:Non-consecutive button: button6
INFO:logitech-g9.svg:Found 10 buttons
INFO:logitech-g9.svg:Found 1 leds

But for this case the Non-consecutive button is intentional. There is a button5 in the profile, but it does not exist as a button on the device itself.
Should this be a special mode for the G9 in the HID++1.0 driver where we ignore the button in the profile, or can we make this a warning instead if error in check-svg.py?

column20:
When looking into why setting macros are not working on the G9 (HID++1-0) I noticed that the G9 svg was missing the wheel left/right buttons, and that thus some buttons were also numbered wrong.
Adds wheel left/right clicks and adjusts button numbering.
(Button5 seems to be configurable in the profile, but no such button
exists on the mouse)

column13: ratbagd: send enums as signed int
column20:
Some of our enums use negative values for an invalid
setting. E.g. RATBAG_BUTTON_ACTION_SPECIAL_INVALID = -1
To allow using the same values in piper we should send the
enum values as signed ints.
Fixes #281
column21:

column13: ratbagd: send enums as signed int
column20:

column21: Patch updated with changes for ratbagctl similar to those in piper. CI passes now

column13: ratbagd: send enums as signed int
column20:
Some of our enums use negative values for an invalid
setting. E.g. RATBAG_BUTTON_ACTION_SPECIAL_INVALID = -1
To allow using the same values in piper we should send the
enum values as signed ints.
Fixes #281
column21:
Hmm, I'm looking at this and now I'm wondering: why don't we have a layer in ratbagd that filters all these invalid values out? We probably need to add something like an Error event in the DBus API so that piper can display something useful to the user but this to me feels like we're keeping ratbagd simple and offloading all the error handling into piper. When really, we should be in control of the DBus API that we never send out-of-range vales.
That piper doesn't check the values and trusts them blindly is a different issue.

column20:
wireless receiver is the same as on g403 and g900.
bluetooth seem to be occasionally working with my dw1820a wifi+bluetooth(4.1) adapter and detected as g603.
tested on ubuntu 18.04.1.
does not work over bluetooth with my intel 9260 wifi+bluetooth(5.0) returning error:

works perfectly over usb wireless adapter.

column21: Closed since #510 got merged

column20:
Allows systems that provide libelogind (which provides a portion of
libsystemd that libratbag uses) to also compile without having to patch
out the rest of the build to remove the full systemd dependency.
This commit:

Adds a systemd swith on meson_options.txt, a boolean set to true as
default to keep expected behaivour
Adds a check on meson.build for the systemd switch and adds
dep_systemd
Guards sections meant to generate systemd service units under the
systemd switch

column21: Thank you!
fwiw, next time just git push -f <remote> <branch> to overwrite. github detects this so you don't have to issue new PRs when you have a change.
Yes I know, I accidentally pushed before adding the new commit.
looks good, but I wonder why the CI failed. Can you double-check that please?

Acording to meson's documentation the executable should exit with code 77 so it gets marked as skipped. They don't mention any alternnative on why a test would be marked as skipped.
http://mesonbuild.com/Unit-tests.html#skipped-tests

/etc/dbus-1/system.d/org.freedesktop.ratbag_devel1.conf is installed by the test, this isn't the normal one that gets installed. So there's something wonky with the install paths. I wonder if the issue is simply that /etc/dbus-1/system.d/ doesn't yet exist and we need to mkdir it
Shouldn't that be handled by the test?
Well that had something to do with it. Now the test is timming out :/
maybe the dbus service doesn't start? or is otherwise restricted? Not sure but you should be able to reproduce this locally with a docker image, just run the same commands and see if it works out.

The dbus service should already be running.
https://www.archlinux.org/news/d-bus-now-launches-user-buses/
I'll deal with this tomorrow.

Here's whats going wrong:
ratbagd.devel error: Failed to start ratbagd: Permission denied
@whot can you give me access to CircleCI? Specifically SSH permissions so that I can debug this issue?

I honestly can't figure out how to do that. You don't show up anywhere in CircleCI (others like phomes do when I click on the invite link). Can you see libratbag in https://circleci.com/add-projects? Maybe you need to create a CircleCI account (or log in with github) once to be known to the system?
Have you tried the local docker approach? that may also be able to reproduce the issue
Probably because I am not in the organization? I tried running the circleci cli tool but that doesn't seem to allow us to interact with the build.
yep, that was it. you were in libratbag but not in the org.

So, it looks like 
  
    
      libratbag/ratbagd/ratbagd.c
    
    
         Line 553
      in
      23ff4e7
    
  
  
    

        
          
           log_error("Failed to start ratbagd: %m\n"); 
        
    
  

 is being triggered. No clue why. Need to do some debugging.

column13: Don't send -1 down the wire from ratbagd
column20:
Supersedes #504
Check each unsigned int we're sending down the dbus API and verify it's not -1. If it is, print an error to the log so we can debug this quicker. This results in the proper DBus error codes so piper can handle the various issues correctly. Right now, it just crashes when it gets a -1 where it expects an unsigned int.

column13: ratbagd: do not warn when converting invalid special action
column20:
In the review of #516 I requested error logging when we converted an invalid special action to an unknown. That turned out to be a mistake.  Clients e.g. ratbagctl ask for all properties, so this getter function gets called often even if the button is not a special action. I only thought that we would call the getter of the actual button type, and that each conversion from invalid to unknown would thus be due to an internal confusion of the type. I was wrong.
We do not want to send the value for an invalid special action as
that is negative 1. Converting to unknown is good enough here so
let's just remove the error logging and convert in silence.
column21:

Clients e.g. ratbagctl ask for all properties, so this getter function gets called often even if the button is not a special action. I only thought that we would call the getter of the actual button type, and that each conversion from invalid to unknown would thus be due to an internal confusion of the type. I was wrong.
We do not want to send the value for an invalid special action as

column20:
In the review of #516 I requested error logging when we converted an invalid special action to an unknown. That turned out to be a mistake.  Clients e.g. ratbagctl ask for all properties, so this getter function gets called often even if the button is not a special action. I only thought that we would call the getter of the actual button type, and that each conversion from invalid to unknown would thus be due to an internal confusion of the type. I was wrong.
We do not want to send the value for an invalid special action as
that is negative 1. Converting to unknown is good enough here so
let's just remove the error logging and convert in silence.
column21: could copy the ratelimit logging bits from libinput as well if we care sufficiently. But this works just fine, thanks

column13: Make ratbagd and ratbagd.py more robust for errors
column20:
First patch makes sure we don't crash out if we ever get None from an array property - which can happen when an error occurs.
The second patch wraps all (well, most) the sd_bus calls that are pure scaffolding into a macro that logs an error if they fail. This way we at least get notified when a basic "open message" or "append value" call fails, causing a property to end up being None.

column13: Read input reports from different endpoint
column20:
This is a bit of work in progress, but is still usable as is. The motivation for pushing this now is the plans for changing from udev for flatpak support in ratbagd which would require changes in the same code.
This PR will add support in libratbag for those devices that receive reports on one endpoint but send the response on another. This is done by mice from both steelseries and cooler master. In this PR we added the functionality needed in libratbag itself and starts to make use of it from the steelseries driver.
More work is needed to read a full profile from the steelseries mice, but @FFY00 has already understood a good part of the protocol needed. I would love to see followup patches with additional data read, and more testing of device/firmware differences.

column20:
We don't have an easy way to query the version of ratbagd itself (ratbag-command --version works though), so let's add --version.
And the default ratbagd process doesn't print anything so we hope it just works rather than hanging. Add a --quiet argument for that mode and in the default startup at least print the devices as we find them.
column21:

And the default ratbagd process doesn't print anything so we hope it just works rather than hanging. Add a --quiet argument for that mode and in the default startup at least print the devices as we find them.

column20:
WIP -  do not merge
Added support for changing DPI, polling rate and colors as well as all the color modes (on/off/cycle/breathing). Also added an SVG file (still WIP, nearly complete).
Of course, feedback, criticisms and suggestions are very welcome.
Regarding the driver:
This mouse uses a new DeviceVersion: version 3. It is a frankensteined combo of version 1 and 2. On one hand, the Rival 600 uses the same command codes as mice in version 1; on the other hand, it uses a very similar protocol for colors and effects as version 2 (Rival310 and Sensei310).
Thus, I am piggybacking on steelseries_write_led_v2() for the LED color protocol, because other than the header field indexes they are identical. I modified construct_cycle_buffer() to retrieve field indexes from a struct steelseries_led_cycle_spec, instead of using hard-coded indexes.
I did this in an attempt to reuse code. Should I keep it like that, or should I revert the changes in v2 and have a completely separate v3?
Also, since steelseries_write_led_v2() is modified, could anyone test with a v2 mouse to verify I didn't break anything?

column21:
I can't see the packet dumps there.
This is the easier way of testing commands I've been able to come up with:
Run hexdump /dev/hidraw0 (should be 0 if you don't have any other HID device connected but it might be different on your system) and keep it opened to read from the mouse.
Then you can send a command using something like this https://gist.github.com/FFY00/faa3065a0fd39681143714c6272d90af (again, should be hidraw1 but it might be other device). If the command returns something, you'll see it popping up in hexdump.
If you need to find out which device is the correct one to read from (/dev/hidrawX), I suggest that you use the command 0x90 (read firmware version) as it should be present there, unless they changed it for some reason.

column21:
Will do 👍
BTW, refactored the led cycle spec to be based on device version instead of usb id:

removed create_cycle_spec()
the function formerly known as steelseries_write_led_v2() is now steelseries_write_led_cycle()
now steelseries_write_led_v2() and steelseries_write_led_v3() are wrapper functions that creates their respective cycle specs and passes it to steelseries_write_led_cycle()

Thus, I am piggybacking on steelseries_write_led_v2() for the LED color protocol, because other than the header field indexes they are identical. I modified construct_cycle_buffer() to retrieve field indexes from a struct steelseries_led_cycle_spec, instead of using hard-coded indexes.
I did this in an attempt to reuse code. Should I keep it like that, or should I revert the changes in v2 and have a completely separate v3?
Also, since steelseries_write_led_v2() is modified, could anyone test with a v2 mouse to verify I didn't break anything?
column21:

pcap (wireshark v. >=1.8)
Inserting the mouse generated packets up to no. 108.
No. 109 and out are the ones generated when starting Steelseries Engine.
So far I got this:
COMMAND     DESCRIPTION                 RESPONSE
0x10        Read firmware version       2 bytes (LE; MSB:major, LSB: minor)
0x16        Read active DPI setting?    1 byte?

EDIT: Just to add, there is one more command in the capture file that triggers a read, but I couldn't make out what it means
Regarding the 0x42:
I could have sworn it didn't work for me without it during previous tests. But when I tested it again to confirm, it worked every time even without it. Weird... Guess it should be changed to unsure for this one as well

column20:
no, not coverity fixes, but really "fix coverity". It doesn't like gcc7 and spews things like undefined type _Float128 by the millions (you can never have enough of those errors, I guess).
So let's give libratbag a special "be nice to coverity" option and let meson define all the types coverity is really unhappy about.

column13: driver-hidpp10: force the single profile to be active
column20:
If we can successfully read a profile but hidpp10_get_current_profile() fails
we end up with one profile, but not set to active. Fix this by always forcing
the single profile to be active.
Fixes #526

column20:
Add support for the Logitech G Pro.  I based this off of the Logitech G203 configuration as these are essentially the same devices Driver, LED and Form factor wise. However the Logitech G Pro supports higher DPI/ improved sensor (up to 12,000 DPI) which is reflected in the new config.
I've been using this as my daily driver for about a week on Ubuntu 18.04 and haven't noticed anything out of the ordinary.

column13: hidpp20: if a command returns with error, return a neg errno
column20:
I'm pretty sure all callers rely on this command to return either 0 or a
negative errno. There's a quirky occasion where if we get a HID error (a
positive number) during hidpp20_special_keys_buttons_get_reporting, that
number eventually ends up as the 'num_controls' value in
hidpp20_special_key_mouse_get_controls().
Since the only time we care about HID++ errors is during
hidpp20_root_get_protocol_version, let's just always return -EPROTO on HID++
errors.
Fixes #558
column21:

errors.

column21:
This does not fix the crash described in libratbag/piper#177. Simply increasing the timeout for the async call does, but I'm not sure if this is just treating the symptom or the cause.
How did you think this would fix the issue? Is the goal here to bypass the need to use DBus' async calls and instead, adding the asynchronisity (?) to ratbagd itself, thereby bypassing the timeout altogether?

column20:
Schedule the actual operation as a callback to handle at the end of the event
loop and return success. The Resync signal will handle the rest.
column21: Scratch that, it does fix the crash. I forgot to systemctl restart ratbagd 😅. However, my question from above still stands, do we need any async DBus stuff in the ratbagd bindings now still?

column20:
Schedule the actual operation as a callback to handle at the end of the event
loop and return success. The Resync signal will handle the rest.
column21:
yes, it makes us completely independent of dbus timeouts by having the async bits implemented by two separate bits in ratbagd.
That was the original intent of the Resync signal - commit always succeeds except for real errors and the rest depends on the device. If it needs 2 min to sync, well, we're good. Playing with dbus timeouts is just a race to find which device takes the longest.
And because it's dbus-independent async (i.e. not the type you'd usually see in dbus bindings) nothing is needed in the ratbagd bindings.

column20:
Schedule the actual operation as a callback to handle at the end of the event
loop and return success. The Resync signal will handle the rest.
column21:
Sorry, I somehow missed your comment here.

And because it's dbus-independent async (i.e. not the type you'd usually see in dbus bindings) nothing is needed in the ratbagd bindings.

I meant, do we still need _dbus_call_async in the bindings now? Turns out we don't, see libratbag/piper#279.

column21: I think we need to implement _on_properties_changed(self, proxy, changed_props, invalidated_props) in each class in the bindings for this to be picked up. Currently, we only listen for certain changes but not all. What would be the best way to get ratbagd to emit Resync with actually changed values? Emitting the Resync signal with dbus-send doesn't seem to trigger it (dbus-send --system --type=signal /org/freedesktop/ratbag1/device/event17 org.freedesktop.ratbag1.Device.Resync)

column13: ratbagd: update all properties before sending out Resync
column20:
Fixes #528
I can see the signals float past on dbus-monitor, but piper doesn't seem to update itself correctly (yet). I think this is an issue with piper rather than ratbagd though.
column21:
The signal itself is just that, a signal. DBus doesn't know what it means, that's just ratbagd context. so the properties need to be updated independently (which is what this commit does). If you hook up dbus-monitor then you can see the updated properties float past.
Anyway, more to your question: add a return RATBAG_ERROR_DEVICE in ratbag_device_commit to make sure commit fails, this way you trigger the resync and the property updates, etc.

column13: ratbagd: set up a simple exit-on-idle
column20:
ratbagd is not something that needs stay around forever just because we
configured a mouse once. We have DBus activation and we don't store anything
anyway, so we might as well exit after a period of inactivity (20 min).
There's a slight race condition where if something comes in at exactly the
20min mark, we may shut down anyway and the messages get lost. This is too
narrow to worry about.

column20:
Tested: device info, get/set DPI, remap button
Possible problem: "report rate" always says 0Hz - maybe mouse does not support this feature?
Still needed: an SVG of the device
Pictures of the device (found at https://support.logitech.com/en_us/product/mx-anywhere2):

Pressing the wheel does not seem to generate any event, it just switches between free/click mode, probably purely mechanically.
The square button in the middle is a "Gesture Button" by definition, but it is actually middle button by default, so I just set the button type to "middle button". The problematic button (#558 (comment)) does not seem to be present on the device, although it has the task_id of "Gesture Button".
Some information about the device is inferred from XML files of a LogiOptions windows app installation. They are at <somewhere>/LogiOptions/Software/Current (I don't quite remember the leading path, sorry).
Please tell me if anything is wrong.

column21:
I did some more testing, mainly about the report rate.
Start ratbagd after connecting the device:
$ ratbagctl rate get event21
0
$ ratbagctl rate get-all event21
500
$ ratbagctl rate set 800 event21
$ ratbagctl rate get event21
800
$ ratbagctl rate get-all event21
500

It seems that device report rate is changed inside ratbagd even if the device does not support it (i.e. no HIDPP_PAGE_ADJUSTABLE_REPORT_RATE). Should it be better to also have a ratbag capability for this HID++ feature?

column20:
Turns out this driver never got updated for the 'new' DPI list provided by
libratbag and thus broke with bacdab2 when we
enforced that DPI list.
Set a fixed DPI list based on the hardcoded values we use elsewhere in this
driver.
column21:
Turns out this driver never got updated for the 'new' DPI list provided by
libratbag and thus broke with bacdab2 when we
enforced that DPI list.
Set a fixed DPI list based on the hardcoded values we use elsewhere in this
driver.

column20:
Hi,
I tried to add support for G Pro Wireless. Basically it worked out of the box (it automatically selected G900) I added an svg file. The only problem is that G900 and G Pro have the same DeviceMatch=usb:046d:c539 and svg file used is still the one for G900 I've removed DeviceMatch from G900 and tested G Pro but I am not sure how to properly solve this. If you have some hints please let me know.
I found some problems with original G Pro commit and fixed them in this commit as well PR #573.

One minor issue is that when the mouse is connected with the cord (it can be used like this as well)  ratbagctl does not find it anymore i.e.

#ratbagctl list
No devices available.

lsusb shows that the device is still present and the mouse works fine.

This is now fixed with the new DeviceMatch.
Very likely the same problem exist for logitech g900 since it also had dual mode (I think).
Thanks for creating and maintaining this awesome lib 👍

Ah, sorry, we crossed streams here. I just reverted the commit that added the g pro because of the various issues with it (see #555) can you rebase yours on top of current git master please? Or better yet, on top of #572 because that fixes the current HEAD so yours is just the addition of the file.
Also, as a general rule: please split unrelated items up into multiple commits, in this case this would be the G Pro fixes as one commit, then yours on top. Makes it much easier to debug, review and (if needed) revert ;)

column21:
is the vid/pid the same when you connect it via USB? I wonder if it changes and it needs an extra DeviceMatch entry.
And AFAIK c539 is the receiver ID, we should really match on the device itself. So c539 is going to be the wrong one for both devices. What does evemu-record say about the IDs? Somewhere in the top 5 lines or so. Maybe attach the udevadm info --export-db output, let's see if there's something interesting in there.

column20:
Works both via bluetooth and with the included universal receiver. The device files for the MX Master had a second USB id, so not sure whether I've missed anything here.
I traced the SVG from Logitech's official top-down image. The side buttons are not visible from that view, so I added an approximation to the image.
The thumb button appears as "Unknown". This is related to #124
Fixes #419

column21: As in Piper, this should probably also now listen to the Resync signal to notify the user of any failure. Do you want to add that to this PR right away?

column13: tools: sync ratbagd.py from Piper - drop async commit
column20:
ratbagd now implements commit as normal always-successful call with a
potential Resync signal later if something failed on the device.
PR just so I can have an extra pair of eyes on the other changes here, thanks!
column21:
As in Piper, this should probably also now listen to the Resync signal to notify the user of any failure. Do you want to add that to this PR right away?

Nah, don't have the time for this atm. It's a bit tricky now anyway, the Resync signal works nice for piper but not so much for ratbagctl which is supposed to exit immediately. We'd have to put a forced wait in for a few seconds just in case it may fail but that makes ratbagctl less useful.

column13: hidpp20: if the button is remapped, use that
column20:
A non-zero value for the remapped field means the button is mapped to that
button.
"diverted" means to decouple it from normal HID reports and report it via
HID++ only. In our case here, we "map" it, which is different.
Fixes button set/button get mismatch listed in #587

Fixes button set/button get mismatch listed in #587

column13: tools: canonicalize path first in udev_device_from_path
column20:
This fixes a problem in which running ratbag-command with the path to a device node symlink (e.g. /dev/logi-g502 -> /dev/input/event4), such as one created by a udev rule, would not work correctly, due to the code failing to resolve the symlink prior to checking for the presence of the "/dev/input/event" prefix.
This resulted in nonsensical error messages (shown below) and the curious inability to run ratbag-command successfully with anything but the actual raw path to the device node itself (e.g. /dev/input/event4 would work fine, but /dev/logi-g502 would not, despite both being valid ways of getting to the same device node).
Error: Can't open '/dev/logi-g502': Success
Error: Device '/dev/logi-g502' is not supported

Note that this same problem also prevented the usage of autogenerated symlinks by udev, i.e. /dev/input/by-id/ and /dev/input/by-path/.

column13: hidpp20: non-rgb leds: switch back to HW control once configured
column20:
As mentioned in the code:
We revert to HW control of the LEDs.
This effectively disable the capability of changing the DPI/profile LEDs, but this allows to make them work with the internal DPI/profile switches.
The net result is:

DPI/profiles can't be controlled (but who wants this?)
The logo can properly controlled

Related: #471
Cc: @dslul

column20:
cc @YoyPa
Add a hack to strip non-ascii symbols from the profile names. Our API promises that the strings we send are UTF-8 (because otherwise we'd get kicked off DBus anyway) but a latin-1 encoded string can be invalid UTF-8, see #617.
Until we have proper encoding/decoding in place, let's hack around this by just dropping anything non-ascii from the profile name. Ideally we should do this in libratbag, but adding it in libratbag is a few LOC, libratbag would require some significant rework.
Fixes #617

column13: circleci: drop scan-build from the jobs to run
column20:
Scan-build is at the point where it gives us too many false positives to be
reliable and they're not easily fixable other than sprinkling
"ignore_clang_sa_mem_leak" comments all over the source.
This caused us to drop F29 from the CI earlier, see 1225f42, but
really we just shouldn't use something that's so unreliable as part of our CI.
The main issue continues to be the use of attribute((cleanup)) but others
give us false positives too.

column20:
Note: this is a DBus API break
First patch namespaces the enums better (#224), but the meat is in the second and third patch (the API break).
Right now we have a set of device capabilities but they're a bit... random? We have separate bits for "resolution" vs "switchable resolution". I think it's better to just export the device capabilities as 'r', 'w', or 'rw'. There are devices where we can't read the config but we can write it, others where we can read but not write.
This is mostly mechanical search/replace, but the third patch has the new DBus API which now sends Capabilities as type a(us) - the enum value followed by a string with the characters for each mode ('r', 'w', 'rw', 'wr', ...).

Right now we have a set of device capabilities but they're a bit... random? We have separate bits for "resolution" vs "switchable resolution". I think it's better to just export the device capabilities as 'r', 'w', or 'rw'. There are devices where we can't read the config but we can write it, others where we can read but not write.

column21:
Something that I thought of since pushing this: RATBAG_DEVICE_CAP_PROFILE_DISABLE and RATBAG_DEVICE_CAP_PROFILE_DEFAULT should be a profile capability, not a device capability. Which means that we need to either think of adding rw to those as well. We can then also rethink the other capabilities because now:

RATBAG_DEVICE_CAP_CONFIGURATION - still useful as flag for write-only devices (I don't think read-only devices exist, short of missing implementations)
RATBAG_DEVICE_CAP_RESOLUTION - implied if we have resolutions, so only the write bit is useful.
RATBAG_DEVICE_CAP_PROFILE - implied if we have profiles
RATBAG_DEVICE_CAP_BUTTON - implied if we have buttons
RATBAG_DEVICE_CAP_LED - implied if we have leds
RATBAG_DEVICE_CAP_BUTTON_KEY and RATBAG_DEVICE_CAP_BUTTON_MACROS is probably better as button flag

So effectively this leaves us with only one useful capability which is the one that tells us whether we can write to it. And - new feature - maybe a new bit that tells us it's not persistent. But all the other ones are implied, which makes me think this patchset isn't that useful and can be replaced with one that drops all of them.
Doubly so because we should assume that we have full access to a device, so the bits are more to tell us where a device doesn't do what we'd expect (e.g. we have LEDs but we can't write to them).

I think it's better to just export the device capabilities as 'r', 'w', or 'rw'. There are devices where we can't read the config but we can write it, others where we can read but not write.

column20:
FTR, first patch is from #630
This patchset drops the device capabilities. They are mostly superfluous because we should simply assume that if we have multiple profiles, we can switch between them and write to them. Same for buttons, etc.
Some of the button caps are now handled by the action types list. And the profile disable/default caps are better handled in the profile (because that's where the set_foo() calls are).
This is of course an API break, the Capabilities property on the device disappears.
Another subtle change: if our name isn't writable, simply don't export it (DBus empty string).

Another subtle change: if our name isn't writable, simply don't export it (DBus empty string).
column21:
Oke, that took less effort than expected (see libratbag/piper#304). One change I had to make in the ratbagd bindings was the following, due to f285b12#diff-4edf8a4ccbbc4924299aa67ad39e8283R388:
@@ -485,7 +455,11 @@ class RatbagdProfile(_RatbagdDBus):
     @GObject.Property
     def name(self):
         """The name of the profile"""
-        return self._get_dbus_property("Name")
+        name = self._get_dbus_property("Name")
+        if not name:
+            name = "Profile {}".format(RatbagdProfile.counter)
+            RatbagdProfile.counter += 1
+        return name
Perhaps we can include this in the linked diff instead, because ratbagd_profile already has the index as a member of its struct.
On second thought, having a default profile name in ratbagd breaks https://github.com/libratbag/libratbag/pull/631/files#diff-ac36f33917b8f80db2c98ab8d229356bR515.

column13: Scramble user visible ids for ratbagctl
column20:
Right now:
$ ratbagctl list
event3: Logitech MX Anywhere 2S         
event5:   Logitech Gaming Mouse G303      
event6:   Logitech G500s Laser Gaming Mouse

This is bad because it encourages users to hardcode the event node in their scripts.  And we don't actually care about the event node anyway. With the patch set from #634:
hidraw0: Logitech MX Anywhere 2S         
hidraw2:   Logitech Gaming Mouse G303      
hidraw4:   Logitech G500s Laser Gaming Mouse

Which is better but still encourages users to hardcode the event node in their scripts. With this glorious patchset:
chinchilla: Logitech MX Anywhere 2S         
hamster:   Logitech Gaming Mouse G303      
woodrat:   Logitech G500s Laser Gaming Mouse

Boom! No more hardcoding because it should be fairly obvious that none of those refer to a specfic syspath. Plus it may encourage people to learn a bit more about rodents, because hands up if you knew that a tuco-tuco existed.
No-one?
See, we like to be educational here too.
FTR: the name assigned is actually static while the hidraw node doesn't change but we could shuffle the array of names.
ratbag-command still uses the device nodes, Piper doesn't display the ID anyway.

column13: Remove the SVG handling from libratbag
column20:
This removes the DBus SVG api but adds a new Device.UsbId property that makes it easier for clients to match devices to the SVG files.
Fixes #628
Matching piper PR: libratbag/piper#305
column21:
Long summary from a meeting @bentiss and I had this morning:
The base requirement is that we have some model-specific identifier that allows us to load the right SVG. How we do this is largely up to us. But one thing really matters: we need to separate what libratbag exports from how piper uses it.
One option is to have an opaque string like chinchilla that stays the same for our models. This provides absolutely no information to the client and forces them to have a database to map those strings into device models. libratbag would have to maintain that database too. That string becomes part of the ABI, forever. We need to make sure that the device remains correctly mapped to that string for the lifetime of libratbag.
The second option is to have a semi-opaque string like logitech-g5 or the advertised model name Logitech G5. This provides better information in that it is at least human-identifiable and makes things like SVG file names easy. However, similar restrictions apply, libratbag needs to maintain a database. If a new model gets released with the same name, we now have to revert to hacks like logitech-g5-2019. We already have devices like the G9x and the G502 that need multiple entries, it's unclear what identifier to use. Because it still has to be treated as opaque string in the client, it carries no more information than chinchilla.
The third option is to have a model identifier in the form of bustype:vid:pid:version. This removes the need for a database on libratbag because we just forward the information from the device. It provides extra information (want to handle BT devices only? skip anything not starting in bluetooth). Likewise if you only want to handle devices from one specific vendor. Plus, if this fails we can blame the vendor instead of us :)
Biggest drawback here is that it's not as human-friendly on the other side. So it'll still require some database to map usb... to logitech-foo.svg but given the drawbacks of the other two approaches, this is just something we have to live with.
Notable changes over the patchset originally submitted:
@bentiss and I agreed that instead of the patchset's (bus, vid, pid) tuple making this a defined string is more flexible. So we define usb:... and bluetooth:..., in the future we may have a ble:... format that is completely different (no VID/PID?)
The version field (was not in the first patchset) means we have an escape where devices re-use VID/PID, we can just bump the version for those.

column13: Remove the SVG handling from libratbag
column20:
This removes the DBus SVG api but adds a new Device.UsbId property that makes it easier for clients to match devices to the SVG files.
Fixes #628
Matching piper PR: libratbag/piper#305
column21:
The second option is to have a semi-opaque string like logitech-g5 or the advertised model name Logitech G5. This provides better information in that it is at least human-identifiable and makes things like SVG file names easy. However, similar restrictions apply, libratbag needs to maintain a database. If a new model gets released with the same name, we now have to revert to hacks like logitech-g5-2019. We already have devices like the G9x and the G502 that need multiple entries, it's unclear what identifier to use. Because it still has to be treated as opaque string in the client, it carries no more information than chinchilla.

A few more arguments against this:

this string would be written by a human, which means it will be error prone. And if we start shipping a device with a bad copy/paste from one file to one other, 2 different mice will have the same product string and we will be screwed. We could partially solve that by adding a check in meson, but that would be extra work
the second extra issue is that it would force libratbag to take the decision on splitting the device based on an assumption on how it will be used. For example, the MX Master can be connected over LUR or bluetooth (and maybe directly from the USB cable). Either libratbag splits this device in 3 which would duplicate the files for no reasons (and will be error prone), either we keep only one device file, but then piper can't take the decision of showing a different SVG if the mouse is wired or not.

Which is why, for all of these reasons, @whot convinced me that we better have a uniquely generated ID, that ratbagd can guarantee its uniqueness and if it's not unique, then we can blame the hardware maker (or the driver).

column13: tools: add a noop notify() function to all our classes

ratbagd uses GObjects and properties so we also make use of notify() a
fair bit. Make sure we don't crash out in ratbagc for that, just add an empty
noop function named notify().
 File "./build/ratbag-command", line 621, in macro
    return RatbagdMacro.from_ratbag(libratbag.ratbag_button_get_macro(self._button))
  File "./build/ratbag-command", line 741, in from_ratbag
    ratbagd_macro.append(type, value)
  File "./build/ratbag-command", line 760, in append
    self.notify("keys")
AttributeError: 'RatbagdMacro' object has no attribute 'notify'

This is a hack, I think we should review how we're using gobjects and normal objects but for now it fixes the crash at least.

working. Restore this, we care about everything but --help and --version in
the second parser.

column13: ratbagd: change the Resolution property to a variant
column20:
Instead of a fixed (uu) with an extra capability flag, let's just make this a
variant defined to be a u or a (uu), depending on whether we have a single or
a separate resolution.
In the ratbagd.py bindings we return a tuple for both, but a simple len()
check will tell us which one it is.

column20:
Fixes #647
Instead of different entry points that depend on each other, let's just export one entry point that tells us what we need. IOW we now take an enum value (action type) and a variant, the latter depends on the action type to be set.
Doesn't affect ratbagd at this point, it's all abstracted.

column21:
The ubuntu failure was nasty.
But at least I could reproduce it reliably on a container, which lead me to:
diff --git a/tools/ratbagd.py b/tools/ratbagd.py
index 7465c03..8dd1e19 100644
--- a/tools/ratbagd.py
+++ b/tools/ratbagd.py
@@ -704,7 +704,7 @@ class RatbagdButton(_RatbagdDBus):
         """
         button = GLib.Variant("u", button)
         self._set_dbus_property("Mapping", "(uv)",
-                [RatbagdButton.ACTION_TYPE_BUTTON, button])
+                (RatbagdButton.ACTION_TYPE_BUTTON, button))
 
     @GObject.Property
     def macro(self):
@@ -725,7 +725,7 @@ class RatbagdButton(_RatbagdDBus):
         """
         macro = GLib.Variant("a(uu)", macro.keys)
         self._set_dbus_property("Mapping", "(uv)",
-                [RatbagdButton.ACTION_TYPE_MACRO, macro])
+                (RatbagdButton.ACTION_TYPE_MACRO, macro))
 
     @GObject.Property
     def special(self):
@@ -744,7 +744,7 @@ class RatbagdButton(_RatbagdDBus):
         """
         special = GLib.Variant("u", special)
         self._set_dbus_property("Mapping", "(uv)",
-                [RatbagdButton.ACTION_TYPE_SPECIAL, special])
+                (RatbagdButton.ACTION_TYPE_SPECIAL, special))
 
     @GObject.Property
     def action_type(self):
On this version of gobject, you can't use arrays when you are writing a tuple.
There is something wrong in the way tests are launched too. There was an exception in the call, but given only the stdout was checked, we do not see the failing setter and the call is considered as good.

Instead of different entry points that depend on each other, let's just export one entry point that tells us what we need. IOW we now take an enum value (action type) and a variant, the latter depends on the action type to be set.

column21:
There is something wrong in the way tests are launched too. There was an exception in the call, but given only the stdout was checked, we do not see the failing setter and the call is considered as good.

The following helps:
diff --git a/tools/ratbagctl.test.in b/tools/ratbagctl.test.in
index 044a119..a961355 100755
--- a/tools/ratbagctl.test.in
+++ b/tools/ratbagctl.test.in
@@ -110,6 +110,8 @@ class TestRatbagCtl(unittest.TestCase):
     def launch_good_test(self, params):
         returncode, stdout, stderr = self.run_ratbagctl(params)
         self.assertEqual(returncode, 0, msg=stderr + stdout)
+        self.maxDiff = None
+        self.assertEqual(stderr, '')
         return stdout
 
     def launch_fail_test(self, params):
We 'just' need to make sure stderr is empty, as gobject silently catches the exception for us

column21: I partly agree but I don't see any reason why we can't have them here too. Why do we even have a .gitignore? None of the entries are actually project specific, this is just to make it easier for the people who want to submit some patches and are not that familiar with git.

column20: Just a really minor enhancement.
column21:
Why do we even have a .gitignore?

IIRC one compelling argument for meson and else was to not ship a .gitignore at all. This let the users to just have their own...

column20: Just a really minor enhancement.
column21:
indeed, we could remove the gitignore and not suffer any side-effects. This is a leftover from autotools which sprinkles stuff all over the source directory in the default invocation.
As a general rule, you shouldn't add directories to gitignore because it really blanks out that whole directory and you don't usually notice until you've pushed a commit that breaks on some other users' computer :)
The build directory is user-specific btw, it's an argument passed in by the user at meason time. Most use build but the docs refer to builddir, I use a few more for different build combinations. Adding user-specific stuff to gitignore is generally not a good idea either.

column13: Support for Roccat Kone Pure Optical Black/White Edition
column20:
WARNING: Do not merge, it will break support for Roccat Kone XTD.
I'm working on adding support for Roccat Kone Pure, specifically Optical Black/White Edition. Before I proceed further I would like some advice in a few areas.
Generally I wanted to take this approach:

Change roccat driver so it can handle both Kone XTD and Kone Pure (is there anyone that can validate my changes using XTD?).
Migrate the driver to new structure with commit() function.
Add support for additional features already supported by ratbag (e.g. LEDs, as I have a working prototype already).

The draft pull request visualizes changes that I needed to make to handle Kone Pure mouse. On one hand it borks existing support for Kone XTD. On the other hand it shows how both these mice differ.


My first question is how to tell the driver which mouse model he needs to communicate with. I saw two examples in the existing codebase - the steelseries driver uses DeviceVersion property (1, 2, 3...) and the hidpp10 driver uses ProfileType property (e.g. G700). I'm not sure why there are already have two different properties already. Unfortunately I would prefer a property named DeviceModel as ProfileType is confusing due to the primary meaning of profiles as a set of configuration values. Thoughts?


Some differences between Pure and XTD could be described in the device files, e.g. DpiRange (100:5000@50 vs 200:8200@50), maybe number of buttons as well.


More serious are remaining differences, namely a) different data structures (USB HID GET/SET_REPORT) and button mappings. One way to handle that is to introduce additional structures (e.g. rename roccat_settings_report to roccat_settings_report_kone_xtd and then add a slightly different roccat_settings_report_kone_pure) and use conditions (if-oriented-programming ;-)) to handle different devices - there are like around 10 places like that. I would probably introduce several helper functions as some existing functions like roccat_read_profile() are already pretty lengthy. Any better ideas? Note that adding support for more Roccat devices would probably require to push further in that direction, as even XTD Optical seems to differ from 'common' XTD (#421).


I started documenting Kone Pure protocol here: https://github.com/hipnoizz/libratbag/wiki/Roccat-Kone-Pure if someone is interested. Some of this found it's place in the codebase, but not everything, so I think it is a worthwhile addition anyway.

column21:
is there anyone that can validate my changes using XTD

I have an XTD, ping me if you need specific testing. I'm also severely ETIME all the time though...

how to tell the driver which mouse model he needs to communicate with.

Exactly like you describe. Those properties are purely implementation-defined and we can change them at will, whenever we feel like it. Pick what you feel comfortable with. DeviceModel can be iffy if you have multiple models sharing the same firmware, but as I said, we can change it anytime anyway.

Some differences between Pure and XTD could be described in the device files

Yep, that would make sense

I would probably introduce several helper functions [...]

What we did for HID++ was to write protocol-only files (hidpp10.c and hidpp20.c) and then a separate driver that uses that protocol (driver-hidpp10.c and driver-hidpp20.c). Since not all devices support all bits of the protocol, this makes the driver easier to read. I think this approach should work for roccat devices too.

column21:
In addition to what @whot said, there is no need to over engineer the device file and try to make it really generic.
We do have generic Logitech device files, because we know well their protocols and we can write one properly. For device we feel uncomfortable having a common driver, there is nothing wrong adding a new one. For example, the Logitech G300 and G600 are similar but completely separated. This avoids having to make device comparisons and keep the drivers simpler.
So one solution could be to rename driver-roccat.c into driver-roccat-kone-xtd.c and have your as driver-roccat-kone-pure.c. This way you could have your driver quicker upstream and collect all of the fame and bug reports from various users :)
And just to add more water here, the drivers and the device files are pure internal component, we do not care about ABI and we can rename whatever we want. So feel free to use the simpler solution for you, and refine it later when time permit.

Some differences between Pure and XTD could be described in the device files, e.g. DpiRange (100:5000@50 vs 200:8200@50), maybe number of buttons as well.


More serious are remaining differences, namely a) different data structures (USB HID GET/SET_REPORT) and button mappings. One way to handle that is to introduce additional structures (e.g. rename roccat_settings_report to roccat_settings_report_kone_xtd and then add a slightly different roccat_settings_report_kone_pure) and use conditions (if-oriented-programming ;-)) to handle different devices - there are like around 10 places like that. I would probably introduce several helper functions as some existing functions like roccat_read_profile() are already pretty lengthy. Any better ideas? Note that adding support for more Roccat devices would probably require to push further in that direction, as even XTD Optical seems to differ from 'common' XTD (#421).


I started documenting Kone Pure protocol here: https://github.com/hipnoizz/libratbag/wiki/Roccat-Kone-Pure if someone is interested. Some of this found it's place in the codebase, but not everything, so I think it is a worthwhile addition anyway.
column21: @whot @FFY00 Since this is bascially merged and there's no active development here, the PR can be closed I guess. But @hipnoizz's wiki link should be noted somewhere. Could be either in the wiki or in the driver itself as a comment.

column13: Support for Roccat Kone Pure Optical Black/White Edition
column20:
WARNING: Do not merge, it will break support for Roccat Kone XTD.
I'm working on adding support for Roccat Kone Pure, specifically Optical Black/White Edition. Before I proceed further I would like some advice in a few areas.
Generally I wanted to take this approach:

Change roccat driver so it can handle both Kone XTD and Kone Pure (is there anyone that can validate my changes using XTD?).
Migrate the driver to new structure with commit() function.
Add support for additional features already supported by ratbag (e.g. LEDs, as I have a working prototype already).

The draft pull request visualizes changes that I needed to make to handle Kone Pure mouse. On one hand it borks existing support for Kone XTD. On the other hand it shows how both these mice differ.


My first question is how to tell the driver which mouse model he needs to communicate with. I saw two examples in the existing codebase - the steelseries driver uses DeviceVersion property (1, 2, 3...) and the hidpp10 driver uses ProfileType property (e.g. G700). I'm not sure why there are already have two different properties already. Unfortunately I would prefer a property named DeviceModel as ProfileType is confusing due to the primary meaning of profiles as a set of configuration values. Thoughts?


Some differences between Pure and XTD could be described in the device files, e.g. DpiRange (100:5000@50 vs 200:8200@50), maybe number of buttons as well.


More serious are remaining differences, namely a) different data structures (USB HID GET/SET_REPORT) and button mappings. One way to handle that is to introduce additional structures (e.g. rename roccat_settings_report to roccat_settings_report_kone_xtd and then add a slightly different roccat_settings_report_kone_pure) and use conditions (if-oriented-programming ;-)) to handle different devices - there are like around 10 places like that. I would probably introduce several helper functions as some existing functions like roccat_read_profile() are already pretty lengthy. Any better ideas? Note that adding support for more Roccat devices would probably require to push further in that direction, as even XTD Optical seems to differ from 'common' XTD (#421).


I started documenting Kone Pure protocol here: https://github.com/hipnoizz/libratbag/wiki/Roccat-Kone-Pure if someone is interested. Some of this found it's place in the codebase, but not everything, so I think it is a worthwhile addition anyway.
column21: I think we can come back here if needed, as long as @hipnoizz doesn't delete his fork.

I don't really understand.
Looking at the downstream bug: https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=1696264 it seems that a meson change disabled the asserts?
How can this be even possible?
I am not happy adding such paper over the fact that there is a meson bug and we can't check if our program works as expected.

column13: test: disable tests relying on assert if NDEBUG is defined
column20:
This happens when building a 'release' build with meson or manually specifying
-Db_ndebug=true.
This just fixes the symptom, we rely too much on assert to always work. Which
isn't good.
column21:
Looking at the assert man page:

If the macro NDEBUG is defined at the moment <assert.h> was last included, the macro assert() generates no code, and hence does nothing at all.  It is not recommended to define NDEBUG  if  using assert() to detect error conditions since the software may behave non-deterministically.

We are in a case where we use assert to detect an error condition, and I do not see why meson would force us to change our program.

column13: test: disable tests relying on assert if NDEBUG is defined
column20:
This happens when building a 'release' build with meson or manually specifying
-Db_ndebug=true.
This just fixes the symptom, we rely too much on assert to always work. Which
isn't good.
column21:
There are two parts to the story here. One is the changed default in meson in Fedora, now reverted. The other one is that someone may build libratbag with extra flags like -DNDEBUG, thus breaking things. The question is whether we want to handle this case, and if so, just block it? A three-line snippet would be enough here:
#ifdef NDEBUG
#error Do not disable NDEBUG
#endif 

[edit: ifndef -> ifdef]

column13: Error out if NDEBUG is defined
column20:
At some point meson #defined NDEBUG depending on the build type, thus
disabling asserts. libratbag relies on those, so let's error out if NDEBUG is
defined.
Related #685
column21:
At some point meson #defined NDEBUG depending on the build type, thus
disabling asserts. libratbag relies on those, so let's error out if NDEBUG is
defined.
Related #685
yeah, it's bloody annoying. 17.10 seems to have dead repos now, 18.04 has the same timeout issue as this one. Needs to be analysed except that I need to find the time for it first.

Ok, found the issue, see the latest commit. software-properties-common installs libnss-systemd which is used by dbus-daemon on startup. Since systemd isn't available everything times out slowly (multiple minutes). And that timeout is also triggered after we install the ratbagd.devel-specific dbus configuration file. DBus doesn't respond during that timeout, so our tests fail waiting for that.
Simply removing libnss-systemd is sufficient to get this working again.

column13: Add battery voltage reporting for newer mice
column20:
Newer mice don't report their battery levels. Instead, they report the voltage read by the SOC. The lghub app does some math with it to figure out the percentage, using some tables shipped with it, but for our purposes I believe having the battery voltage (in millivolts) and the status (charging, wireless charging, charged, discharging...) should suffice.
This is related to this piper issue and the discussion there.

I think there has already been some discussion in #222.
So basically, thanks a lot for the code, but I am not sure we want to merge this in libratbag. Battery is a feature that needs to be monitored all the time, and having it in libratbag is not the place.
We should really port this code to the kernel, and thanks to @jwrdegoede we have the code merged in v5.2, so adding those tiny bits in the kernel should be easier now (at least over the lightspeed connector).
So keeping this opened, for references, but I am not sure we should merge the code now, as this would be just for documentation purposes.

column13: meson: add 'sphinx-build' to sphinx executable name list
column20: We currently assume the user is using Python 2 as default (over Python 3) and so they renamed the Sphinx Python 3 executable to sphinx-build{3,-3}. The default name is sphinx-build and is usually kept when using Python 3 as the default Python version. With Python 2 dying in 7 months (https://pythonclock.org/) and Sphinx officially dropping Python 2 (sphinx-doc/sphinx@9412bd7) this seems safe to merge.

so the distributions should start

Fedora 30 names it sphinx-build for the python3 version, but Fedora 29 still uses sphinx-build for the python2 one. That has around 6months left. Not sure about other distros.
But unless all major distributions have finished renaming it, we'll just introduce weird errors, especially in the documentation that our users don't care about. So I'd say we leave it as-is and think about it again in a year or two.
Looks like the dbus-daemon binary was renamed or it wasn't pulled as a dependency.

yup, f30 replaced the defaults with dbus-broker but I haven't figured out yet how to start this from the commandline instead of as a dbus service. Meanwhile, we can get by with the old dbus-daemon, good enough until that gets fully retired.

column13: hidpp10: fix segfault for the c531 (and possibly other 27MHz receivers)
column20:
hidpp10_read_memory will return the HID++ error if the request fails.
right now, the error code from hidpp10_read_memory is transparently
passed through hidpp10_onboard_profiles_read_macro. This is problematic
because hidpp10_onboard_profiles_parse_macro only aborts on rc < 0 and
HID++ error are > 0.
Signed-off-by: Filipe Laíns lains@archlinux.org

Is this the right approach. Do we want hidpp10_onboard_profiles_read_macro to keep hidpp10_read_memory's error code? Or should I overwrite rc when we see that hidpp10_read_memory failed?

column20:
when we read the memory from the device we already align the offset so
that it matches the end of the sector. for ex, for a 255 sector size the
offset will be set to 255-16.
when we copy the memory (using memcpy) we just copy the bytes that will
finish filling the buffer, ignoring that the offset was aligned. we need
to copy the full 16 bytes, otherwise it will fail when sector_size does
not align with 16.
Signed-off-by: Filipe Laíns lains@archlinux.org

column20:
when we read the memory from the device we already align the offset so
that it matches the end of the sector. for ex, for a 255 sector size the
offset will be set to 255-16.
when we copy the memory (using memcpy) we just copy the bytes that will
finish filling the buffer, ignoring that the offset was aligned. we need
to copy the full 16 bytes, otherwise it will fail when sector_size does
not align with 16.
Signed-off-by: Filipe Laíns lains@archlinux.org
column21:
Sure. But basically the 8100 feature doesn't allow us to read past the end of the sector, so we position the offset to prevent us from reading past it (we read 16 bytes at a time so we position it at sector_size - 16).
We are then are are using min(count, 16) to calculate the size to copy, which would be valid if we didn't align the offset. But as we align the offset we need to copy the full 16 bytes to the memory.
Example (to also use as documentation):
Given a sector_size of 64
Read 16 bytes at 0x00 (total 16 bytes read)
Read 16 bytes at 0x10 (total 32 bytes read)
Read 16 bytes at 0x20 (total 48 bytes read)
Read 16 bytes at 0x30 (total 64 bytes read)

Given a sector_size of 70
Read 16 bytes at 0x00 (total 16 bytes read)
Read 16 bytes at 0x10 (total 32 bytes read)
Read 16 bytes at 0x20 (total 48 bytes read)
Read 16 bytes at 0x30 (total 64 bytes read)
Read 16 bytes at 0x36 (total 70 bytes read)

0x36 = 0x46 (70 dec) - 0x10 (16 dec)
After we read at 0x36 we need to copy the full 16 bytes. Using min(count, 16) makes us only copy 6 bytes. This was probably leftover code.

column13: hidpp20: fall back to firmware profiles on a profile by profile basis
column20:
currently if any use profile is not valid we fallback to the firmware
profiles. this is quite annoying because the user might have only one
valid profile. this patch will keep valid profiles and only fallback to
firmware profiles on a profile by profile basis.
Signed-off-by: Filipe Laíns lains@archlinux.org

fall back on the normal case if that fails.

column13: tools: print the Model in ratbagctl info
Drop the custom git sha for ratbagd.devel
column20:
After spending way too much time working around the git sha instead of getting useful stuff done, I've decided to drop it. Our .devel tools are supposed to be for developers but right now they get in the way more than anything - try to debug why ratbagd crashes when you're running a ratbagctl.test, it's insane.
Anyway, first bunch of patches replaces the org.freedesktop.ratbag_devel1_$gitsha with just org.freedesktop.ratbag_devel1 as busname. Nothing too exciting here. Second-to-last patch moves installing the dbus file from the tool box to ratbagd.devel directly, this way it can just be started as-is.
Last patch is just a cosmetic fix unrelated, because we can't be pretty enough.

column13: Add the ability to load test devices via JSON
column20:
Right now, we have a hardcoded test device with "magic" values that the tests just have to know. This makes it hard to expand the tests, because it's not obvious which value can be changed without breaking tests or making things worse.
This PR replaces that test device with a new DBus call to load a test device based on a JSON file. That
most basic one (1 profile, 1 resolution, etc.) and adds a new devel DBus API to load a JSON file with the data to merge into the test device. This makes the test more flexible and more obvious too - it's clear why we can test for say dpi 1300.
I'm planning to squash the test changes into one commit but for easier reviewing it's separated out.
The JSON parsing doesn't have a lot of error checking and is a bit hacky, but since this is a developer-only testing interface anyway crashing or asserting isn't the worst of all things.

Seems good from a rough point of view (I'll need to read it more carefully later today).
The one thing @FFY00 is working on in https://github.com/libratbag/ratbag-emu is to have the same JSON description of a test device so he can make sure to have a known state before starting the CI on the specific REST endpoint.
So I made 1+1 in my head and thought that we might be able to use the same Json description so we can test the dbus API and the ratbag basic test driver with or without ratbag-emu (how wonderful would that be?)

column13: Add a APIVersion field to ratbagd
column20:
Synchronizing piper and libratbag is a pain, especially if one runs from a PPA and the other runs from flatpak. Usually something just blows up and then we get to figure out which package doesn't match.
We haven't done anything about this in the past because the stable DBus API was always just around the corner. Let's give up on that hope and add a specific field with the version so it's easier to force the compatibility. We can remove that in a few decades when we finally finish the API.
column21:

column20: Fixes #774
column21: 0x8070 has been deprecated in favor of 0x8071. This new feature introduces the concept of low power effects. For each led we have an alternative effect that is triggered in low power mode. This patch only declares those leds, it does not allow us to configure them. It also declares a powersave and poweroff timeout. @whot do we want to support this?

column20: Fixes #774
column21: I'd say no, we don't. at least not at this point, we have enough tricky other features that we don't properly support and exposing this is going to be flimsy at best. If anything, we could hack this in the driver that we automatically pick a low-power equivalent mode where appropriate. But I don't think we need to expose this in the UI
