column13: hidpp20: fallback to 1st profile when no 8100 profile is active
column20:
When the windows driver puts a device host mode it will mark all 8100
profiles as disabled. If no 8100 profile is enabled no libratbag profile
will get enabled. This patch prevents this by marking the first profile
as enabled if no profile is already enabled.
Signed-off-by: Filipe Laíns lains@archlinux.org
column21:
When the windows driver puts a device host mode it will mark all 8100
profiles as disabled. If no 8100 profile is enabled no libratbag profile
will get enabled. This patch prevents this by marking the first profile
as enabled if no profile is already enabled.
Signed-off-by: Filipe Laíns lains@archlinux.org

column13: hidpp20: remove errors when using the 8071 feature
column20: We were getting an invalid effect count so we were trying to read effects with an invalid ID, resulting in HID++ errors. This PR fixes that.
column21: We were getting an invalid effect count so we were trying to read effects with an invalid ID, resulting in HID++ errors. This PR fixes that.

@bentiss I didn't do some of the things you asked me:

Start ratbag-emu using Popen: this is tricky to integrate with pytest, it's the same issue I had in the ratbag-emu test suite.  If you think it's worth to spend more time making this work let me know.

column21:
I am now starting ratbag-emu from pytest, you might want to test that.

Hmm, that's a progress, but there are at least 2 issues:

hardcoding python won't work on Fedora, we need to call python3 there
we need to install ratbag-emu globally (or maybe adjust $PYTHON_PATH), so this is not very handy for development

IMO, we would need to use the various capabilities of meson to be able to work around those 2 issues. IOW, not something to tackle right now, so please add a # TODO

I'd like to take a few more days before we hit the merge button on this PR. I really don't have the time right now to review the code, and I wonder if we should not have a more mature api on ratbag-emu first.
Don't take it personally, sending this PR means you achieved one big chunk of your internship. But OTOH, I would like to take a little bit more time to think about it before we introduce a dependency on libratbag to a distinct project.

Python 3.7.1 (default, Nov 23 2018, 10:01:49)
[GCC 8.2.1 20181105 (Red Hat 8.2.1-5)] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
>>> import hidpp
>>> f = open('/dev/hidraw1', 'r+b')
>>> base = hidpp.hidpp_device()
>>> hidpp.hidpp_device_init(base, f.fileno())
>>> dev = hidpp.hidpp20_device_new(base, 0xff)
>>> hidpp.hidpp20_feature_get_name(0x8100)
'HIDPP_PAGE_ONBOARD_PROFILES'
>>> hidpp.new_uint8_tp()
<Swig Object of type 'uint8_t *' at 0x7f865198fb70>
>>> feature_index = hidpp.new_uint8_tp()
>>> feature_type = hidpp.new_uint8_tp()
>>> feature_version = hidpp.new_uint8_tp()
>>> hidpp.hidpp_root_get_feature(dev, 0x8100, feature_index, feature_type, feature_version)
0
>>> hidpp.uint8_tp_value(feature_index)
14

Signed-off-by: Benjamin Tissoires benjamin.tissoires@gmail.com
Signed-off-by: Filipe Laíns lains@archlinux.org

Python 3.7.1 (default, Nov 23 2018, 10:01:49)
[GCC 8.2.1 20181105 (Red Hat 8.2.1-5)] on linux
Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.

>>> feature_type = hidpp.new_uint8_tp()
>>> feature_version = hidpp.new_uint8_tp()

Signed-off-by: Filipe Laíns lains@archlinux.org
column21:
I understand the need for a proper python API, but OTOH, the idea is just to provide access to the C code of the hidpp.c files. What we want to achieve here is to ensure that each HID++ feature implemented in ratbag-emu can be trusted.
Ideally, I think we should just copy/paste the c files in a pytest fixture and generate the wrapper there, so that it keeps getting internal to ratabg-emu and we do not export it. Problem is, hidpp*.[ch] indirectly depend on libratbag-private.h.
Given that the .so is not installed, as long as we put the proper warnings, we should be safe.
Side note: I really wish we started libratabg as a python library, that would have saved a bunch of time :(

I had a look at the libratbag-private.h dependency and it falls into the same category. Disentangling is possible but effort for little gain other than correctness. So... not ideal either, let's just go with the swig bindings as you have them here.

column21:
c539 is the ID of the receiver, we don't use it anymore. The hid-logitech-dj kernel driver should be able to create a device-specific hidraw node. Can you try to find the internal ID of your mouse?
You can use dmesg:
$ dmesg | grep logitech
[68607.357898] logitech-djreceiver 0003:046D:C539.00F8: hidraw6: USB HID v1.11 Keyboard [Logitech USB Receiver] on usb-0000:00:14.0-1.3.4/input0
[68607.418151] logitech-djreceiver 0003:046D:C539.00F9: hiddev3,hidraw7: USB HID v1.11 Mouse [Logitech USB Receiver] on usb-0000:00:14.0-1.3.4/input1
[68607.477849] logitech-djreceiver 0003:046D:C539.00FA: hiddev4,hidraw8: USB HID v1.11 Device [Logitech USB Receiver] on usb-0000:00:14.0-1.3.4/input2
[68607.538098] logitech-djreceiver 0003:046D:C539.00FA: device of type eQUAD Lightspeed (0x0c) connected on slot 1
[68607.549151] logitech-hidpp-device 0003:046D:4085.00FB: HID++ 4.2 device connected.
[68607.605928] logitech-hidpp-device 0003:046D:4085.00FB: input,hidraw9: USB HID v1.11 Keyboard [Logitech G604 ] on usb-0000:00:14.0-1.3.4/input2:1

Here 4085 is the ID of my mouse. The ID of your mouse should also start with 4.

column13: data: add wireded ID to G502 Hero Wireless
column20:
Added support for Logitech G502 Lightspeed.
Followed guide on wiki as good as possible.
Been using this device file with no issues for a while now.
column21:
I didn't know about the receiver.
However, I tried finding the internal id of the mouse with the dmesg method(see below).
This returns a id that is indeed already existing, however when I run libratbag without my modifications It will not detect my mouse.
Ill try to find out why this is.
$ dmesg | grep logitech
[ 2916.264487] logitech-djreceiver 0003:046D:C539.003C: hidraw0: USB HID v1.11 Keyboard [Logitech USB Receiver] on usb-0000:00:14.0-3/input0
[ 2916.325363] logitech-djreceiver 0003:046D:C539.003D: hiddev0,hidraw1: USB HID v1.11 Mouse [Logitech USB Receiver] on usb-0000:00:14.0-3/input1
[ 2916.384527] logitech-djreceiver 0003:046D:C539.003E: hiddev1,hidraw2: USB HID v1.11 Device [Logitech USB Receiver] on usb-0000:00:14.0-3/input2
[ 2916.442728] logitech-djreceiver 0003:046D:C539.003E: device of type eQUAD Lightspeed (0x0c) connected on slot 1
[ 2916.448048] logitech-hidpp-device 0003:046D:407F.003F: input,hidraw4: USB HID v1.11 Keyboard [Logitech G502] on usb-0000:00:14.0-3/input2:1
[ 2927.975940] logitech-hidpp-device 0003:046D:407F.003F: HID++ 4.2 device connected.

column13: data: add wireded ID to G502 Hero Wireless
column20:
Added support for Logitech G502 Lightspeed.
Followed guide on wiki as good as possible.
Been using this device file with no issues for a while now.
column21:
Could you stop the daemon and run it manually with verbosity?
Make sure the ratbagd service is stopped (if you have it enabled) and kill all daemon instances, killall ratbagd.
ratbagd --verbose=raw

column20:
Added support for Logitech G502 Lightspeed.
Followed guide on wiki as good as possible.
Been using this device file with no issues for a while now.
column21:
I found the device should be plugged in before ratbagd is run.
Also in addition to that, I found that while the mouse is using the wireless dongle it does indeed work in the current version. It does not while it is connected using a wire.(see bottom code block for ratbagd output)

column13: data: add wireded ID to G502 Hero Wireless
column20:
Added support for Logitech G502 Lightspeed.
Followed guide on wiki as good as possible.
Been using this device file with no issues for a while now.
column21:
Also in addition to that, I found that while the mouse is using the wireless dongle it does indeed work in the current version. It does not while it is connected using a wire.(see bottom code block for ratbagd output)

Yes, that's #785.
Can you change the PR to just add the wired ID to logitech-g502-hero-wireless.device?

column13: data: add wireded ID to G502 Hero Wireless
column20:
Added support for Logitech G502 Lightspeed.
Followed guide on wiki as good as possible.
Been using this device file with no issues for a while now.
column21: And I made a typo in the commit message 🤦‍♀️.

I am pretty sure there are devices that need short commands instead of long. IIRC we had the case in the kernel and this backfired (or maybe this was only for HID++ 1.0 devices).
One thing the kernel is about to do: https://patchwork.kernel.org/patch/11184749/ (the second hunk) -> if the device doesn't export a HID++ short report ID, we can detect it and convert every request to use longs instead.

According to the HID++ 2.0 spec all devices should tolerate long reports. This might not be true in the real world though.
What we should actually do is abstract the report type away and replace with a smart function that will only use long reports when necessary and handle the cases where the devices don't support a certain report type.

What we should actually do is abstract the report type away and replace with a smart function that will only use long reports when necessary and handle the cases where the devices don't support a certain report type.

looks good to me. This is similar to what the kernel is working on.
I am going to drop the optimal approach and just make a sanity check here.

I am going to drop the optimal approach and just make a sanity check here.

sorry, EPARSE - what does that mean?

I am just going to add a check to see if the device supports certain report types and overwrite the report type in the message before sending if not supported.
Now that I am re-reading my message I see how abstract it was 😁.

This is ready for review. @bentiss @whot
Summary: Some devices don't support short report types. This patch introduces hidpp_get_supported_report_types which will check the supported report types. hidpp20_request_command_allow_error was changed to adjust the report type in case it is not supported.
Actually no, this has an issue. Please don't merge.
Sorted. It's ready now.

column13: Give a more specific error message if user cannot reach ratbagd
column20:
If access failed, e.g. due to insufficient permissions, don't confuse
the user by reporting an API mismatch.
This is a minimal improvement to target issue #802. As, if access is
restricted to a group, that group is known in Meson, it would even be
possible to report that group in the error message. But, that would
require converting ratbagd.py to a template or finding some other way to
inject that information at build time.

column20:
Renamed filenames to avoid brackets, and added a check to the meson.build
script to throw a build error when we find an illegal character in a filename.
Should close #800
The error in the build script could become a warn, but that pushes up the meson version required to 0.44. There is already a build warning suggesting the minimum required is 0.50, but I don't know if that warning fails gracefully on older versions or not.

column21: Yes, I restarted it.
Hum, maybe this was a false positive as it seemed to be working before?

meson has a bug where it still warns about these things even when the offending command is wrapped in meson version checks. e.g. we have
if meson.version().version_compare('<0.48.0')
 ....

and it still warns about the import('python') bit.
The second warning (install arg in configure file) is valid afaict but since it only affects the ratbagctl/lur-command man pages so I've mostly gone "meh" on that so far :)
Closing this then.

I switched the Fedora CI to F31 in #843 just now but for ubuntu I reckon it makes sense to keep 19.04 as a trigger for breaking things too hard. There's a large user-base on 19.04 still so let's not make our life harder than needed - asking them to install meson from pip is not helping our time bottlenecks.
sigh, I don't know why it was shown was 'all tests passed' but diff is missing and the CI fails right now. See #844 for the fix

column13: ratbagd: make raw the default verbosity level
column20: TBH --verbose is not really that useful. We receive a several reports where the users paste the log with --verbose and 99.9% of the cases that is not helpful, we need --verbose=raw. I think it would make sense for raw to be the default level when --verbose is specified.
column21: TBH --verbose is not really that useful. We receive a several reports where the users paste the log with --verbose and 99.9% of the cases that is not helpful, we need --verbose=raw. I think it would make sense for raw to be the default level when --verbose is specified.

column13: drivers: add Roccat Kone Pure driver
column20:
What I basically did was taking #682, copying the device specific changes and putting it in an own driver, as it was suggested in that PR. However first of all I don't even have that mouse so I really can't test it and secondly I don't think it's a very nice solution since 90% of the code is duplicated.
But if someone can test it and everything works, I thinks it better to have this than having nothing. If someone has the mouse and wants to add features, @hipnoizz provided some informations in his wiki, but sadly it looks like he is not actively developing the support anymore.

column21:
whoah, a non-unified diff. there's a blast from the past :) I recommend alias diff='diff -u' in your shell config because no-one uses non-unified diffs anymore but diff itself will never change the default.
could be that the drivers can be merged, mostly depends on @stephanlachnit and whether he wants to do that effort. However - given that even he doesn't have that device and we haven't really seen a lot of feedback here I think it's safer to just leave them separate - that way a change in one doesn't inadvertently break the other one without us ever being able to test them.

column13: ratbagd: print two verbose messages at startup
column20:
When no device is present, starting ratbagd even with --verbose prints exactly
nothing. Let's be more verbose here to give the user an indication that
something's happening. The user wants everything, is probably willing to
accept anything but in the end all we can say is that we have nothing.
Related to #862

accept anything but in the end all we can say is that we have nothing.
Related to #862

column13: libratbag: only log to stderr for error messages
column20:
This was copied from libinput and made sense while libratbag was a library -
we want "unhandled" messages to end up somewhere and stderr is the most likely
candidate here.
Now that we always run within ratbagd and it's all effectively inseperable,
just log to stdout for anything below error.
column21:
This was copied from libinput and made sense while libratbag was a library -
we want "unhandled" messages to end up somewhere and stderr is the most likely
candidate here.
Now that we always run within ratbagd and it's all effectively inseperable,
just log to stdout for anything below error.

column13: data: add a test for unifying receiver IDs
column20:
We don't want any device files that use the receiver itself as a match so
let's test for that. In virtually all cases this means the user must update
the kernel and hope support for that receiver is already present in that
version.
@bentiss, @FFY00 - what are the new receiver IDs again? I've only added 0xc52b and 0xc532 here.

libratbag: add option to disable resolutions

column21:
So, I think the implementation plan is:
- Add is_enabled and allows_disabling properties to resolutions
- Implement a new method to in the driver to enable/disable resolutions (only called when allows_disabling is set)
- Make the HID++ 2.0 driver enable allows_disabling for each resolution if the 0x8100 (onboard profiles)
I am pretty sure setting the DPI to 0 to disable it only works in the 0x8100 feature but I will need to check.
Some more details: is_enabled should default to true and allows_disabling should default to false.
@whot do you remember where in the code we create the resolutions (set the defaults)?
@stephanlachnit I know this can be a lot, so please feel free to ask anything, you could also drop by the IRC (#libratbag on freenode) for live chat.

column21:
My idea here was basically "defining" that removing means setting to zero. What the driver actually does is a different thing, setting a dpi to zero is prohibited by libratbag anyway, so we can just use this as a sneaky shortcut. It has the advantage, that the implementation in the drivers (right now only hidpp20) and in piper is way easier.

On a second step we would make piper aware of the added properties.

Working on it in libratbag/piper#448

@stephanlachnit I know this can be a lot, so please feel free to ask anything, you could also drop by the IRC (#libratbag on freenode) for live chat.

Thanks, I joined it. First time on a IRC sorry for joining 5 times.

Sure, but please do it in a separate commit.

Will do it once the rest is sorted out.

What the driver actually does is a different thing, setting a dpi to zero is prohibited by libratbag anyway, so we can just use this as a sneaky shortcut. That is fine for internal API but it's not a great solution for the public DBus API. I really want to have an enable/disable property in DBus.

column20:
Adds functionality to disable resolutions from a static resolution list.
Adds hidpp20 driver implementation for this functionality.
Some other minor changes, see commits.

column21:
My idea here was basically "defining" that removing means setting to zero. What the driver actually does is a different thing, setting a dpi to zero is prohibited by libratbag anyway, so we can just use this as a sneaky shortcut. It has the advantage, that the implementation in the drivers (right now only hidpp20) and in piper is way easier.

That is fine for internal API but it's not a great solution for the public DBus API. I really want to have an enable/disable property in DBus.

If the mouse can add resolutions dynamically, it really makes sense to add DBus APIs for adding/removing resolutions, and we should add an own capability for that. In the static case, where the mouse even reports "disabled" resolutions (aka zero dpi), a DBus property would be nice to have, but not strictly necessary* since everything is well defined (see my note at definition of RATBAG_RESOLUTION_CAP_DISABLE).
*Edit this is only the case when we don't have RATBAG_RESOLUTION_SEPARATE_XY_RESOLUTION. So with current supported devices no problem, but it's not a good solution, because then it will start to get messy. So a new resolution property it is. Developing and debugging with DBus is kinda new to me, and since I have an exam in a week I probably won't work on this PR until the holidays. I will still work on the piper side of things if you want to review there as well.

column21: Some extra comments on the behavior. When disabling a rtabag resolution (not the internal HID++ one) you should not set it 0 dpi, otherwise we will lose the data about the dpi level. We want users to be able to enable and disable resolutions without losing the dpi level they have stored there. Please fix this behavior before the final review.

column21:
Without the resync behavior everything went faster as expected. Rebased everything, can now be reviewed (again). Works also with this piper PR: libratbag/piper#448.
@FFY00 I squashed the driver debug logs together as suggested, and also added a "committing" and "committed" output so it's a nice visible block, for example:
ratbag: profile 0 resolution 1: set enabled
ratbag: profile 0 resolution 1: set 6500 dpi
ratbag: profile 0 resolution 1: set active
driver: committing
driver: profile 0 resolution 0: 1000 dpi
driver: profile 0 resolution 1: 6500 dpi, active
driver: profile 0 resolution 2: 0 dpi
driver: profile 0 resolution 3: 0 dpi
driver: profile 0 resolution 4: 0 dpi
driver: committed

Let me quickly go through the main changes:

I added a new is_disabled property and disabled resolution capability. This needs to be handled internally by the driver, so no super big changes to the common code are actually required here.
Bunch of changes go to the addition of the new DBus API interface, but that's mostly copied from the active/default properties.
The test driver needed some adjustments, and some test had do be edited to not just check for the word disabled.
Sometimes I changed the order in the code, so everywhere it's now first "active", then "disabled" (sometimes after that "enabled") and in the end "default". Makes it easier to find code, but maybe looks a little bit confusing when you look at the git changes.

column21:
Tip: Use fixup commits to resolve the issues.
https://fle.github.io/git-tip-keep-your-branch-clean-with-fixup-and-autosquash.html
Example workflow:
(fix issue)
$ git add -p
(select the changes you want in the commit)
$ git commit --fixup HEAD~1 (creates a fixup commit related to the penultimate commit)
$ git rebase -i --autosquash master (I usually do origin/master with origin being https://github.com/libratbag/libratbag.git)

column20:
The first commit adds -Wno-address-of-packed-member which is triggered by accessing metadata->lgs02.* in hidpp10.c, example:
https://github.com/libratbag/libratbag/blob/master/src/hidpp10.c#L1413
This warnings spit out a lot of spam making it more difficult to identify other ones.
column21:
The first commit adds -Wno-address-of-packed-member which is triggered by accessing metadata->lgs02.* in hidpp10.c, example:
https://github.com/libratbag/libratbag/blob/master/src/hidpp10.c#L1413
This warnings spit out a lot of spam making it more difficult to identify other ones.

column20:
The first commit adds -Wno-address-of-packed-member which is triggered by accessing metadata->lgs02.* in hidpp10.c, example:
https://github.com/libratbag/libratbag/blob/master/src/hidpp10.c#L1413
This warnings spit out a lot of spam making it more difficult to identify other ones.
column21: hmm, after reading about this warning, I think it may be more prudent to just go and fix those instances instead of papering over it. While not an immediate problem, it could become an issue if these are ever run on ARM, or some ARMs anyway.

column20:
The first commit adds -Wno-address-of-packed-member which is triggered by accessing metadata->lgs02.* in hidpp10.c, example:
https://github.com/libratbag/libratbag/blob/master/src/hidpp10.c#L1413
This warnings spit out a lot of spam making it more difficult to identify other ones.
column21: We are working with strings, which are just char arrays, so the warning does not apply here. The problem would be if we were taking, for example, the pointer of a 64bit int. The compiler could pass that pointer directly to an ARM instruction which was expecting the pointer to be aligned. As we are working with byte arrays there's nothing to worry about. There isn't really anything to fix, we need to access the data, there's no way of accessing that data without triggering the warning. The alternative to not having -Wno-address-of-packed-member would be to put #pragmas in the code ignoring the warning on the places we access the string.

column20:
The first commit adds -Wno-address-of-packed-member which is triggered by accessing metadata->lgs02.* in hidpp10.c, example:
https://github.com/libratbag/libratbag/blob/master/src/hidpp10.c#L1413
This warnings spit out a lot of spam making it more difficult to identify other ones.
column21: Hum, I stand corrected. We are declaring name and macro_names as uint16_t arrays, which could cause trouble.

Rebased single commit from whot/libratbag/wip/custom-vtables against master. Goal is to merge this before #870.
That being said, I think we should not just update the DBus API but also all the drivers, meaning replacing ratbag_profile_set_enabled with ratbag_profile_set_enabled so we don't have even more  confusion with negations. But for now this should be enough, maybe will do all the driver work in the future.
column21:
unless you have a very specific schedule that you can keep and you merge both within a day or two, it's better to bump every time. Otherwise the whole point of the version making sure both ends support it correctly is moot. And it's just an integer, we're not going to run out of those for ... a while.
Bumping the version is a lot quicker than having to deal with bugs when the two repos are out of sync despite the error message telling users to update both.

column21: True, libratbag isn't really regular with it's realeases. Speaking of that: I asked @FFY00 to do a release before the Ubuntu 20.04 import freeze to get the latest devices in this LTS releases which probably a lot of people will use, so if he wants to merge this he could add a version bump there, else I'm gonna close it again and add a version bump in #870 when I have time to rebase it.

column21:
True, libratbag isn't really regular with it's realeases

Well, we don't have a regular development cycle, this is just done as best effort.

Speaking of that: I asked @FFY00 to do a release before the Ubuntu 20.04 import freeze to get the latest devices in this LTS releases which probably a lot of people will use, so if he wants to merge this he could add a version bump there, else I'm gonna close it again and add a version bump in #870 when I have time to rebase it.

I think it's maybe best if we leave it out since I don't have much time to look at this and it's not that important.

column21:
The ERR_INVALID_FUNCTION_ID error is a bit weird. I should use hidpp20_color_led_info.ext_caps to make sure the device supports the features that we are using.
Effect 5 is the starlight effect which we don't know to write, I guess we should change that log msg to something like Unsupported effect %d and set it to debug. It is not a problem for us not knowing how to write that effect as we don't touch the memory unless the user explicitly changes the led.

Special case here is the test_driver struct, without the extern gcc seems to

strcmp the test driver name.

column13: data: add support for Logitech G815 keyboard
column21:
Do the leds change the moment after you apply changes? Here they don't, I need to press one of the M keys. Maybe I am in a funny firmware.

They do not change for me either until I've changed to a different profile and back. I'm guessing piper and ratbagctl aren't or can't send commands to reload the profile after committing it to the keyboard?

column13: data: add support for Logitech G815 keyboard
column21:
Looks good to me. Did you test it?
Also, you should squash the commits into one (they will be squashed when merging anyway, but just for the future).

Noted on the squashing.
It works as well as can be expected. Obviously it doesn't add support for individual key leds or anything like that, but the keboard is recognized and configurable with ratbagctl, and I can turn that horrible default rainbow cycling off! Only thing I've found so far that's not working is detailed in issue #909 but I can't see that that's anything to do with the device file.
Also, of course, it's not fully working in piper, as it's just showing the 404-rat, and button 0 and 1 (G1 and G2) only have options for left or right handed, but I guess that's beyond the scope of both libratbag and this PR?

column13: data: add support for Logitech G815 keyboard
column21: Piper doesn't know that we added keyboards to libratbag, so this is expected.

column13: data: add support for Logitech G815 keyboard
column21:
They do not change for me either until I've changed to a different profile and back. I'm guessing piper and ratbagctl aren't or can't send commands to reload the profile after committing it to the keyboard?

The daemon can send that command, however I tried it and it still does not trigger the LED change. I tried several different things but none of them seem to update the LEDs. I will query Logitech about this.

It works as well as can be expected.

I also tried it and I can change the LEDs and remap the G keys.

Obviously it doesn't add support for individual key leds or anything like that, but the keboard is recognized and configurable with ratbagctl, and I can turn that horrible default rainbow cycling off! Only thing I've found so far that's not working is detailed in issue #909 but I can't see that that's anything to do with the device file.

Yes, out of scope for now.
If we change the g9x device file anyway, we could also merge the g9x and the g9x CoD device files, they are the same anyway (except for the usb id). If you want you can do it, else I would add it.

column21:
I don't understand why we need to do this. I don't see any reason to merge the two .device files.

If we want to change their properties, we don't want to do it twice (like with this PR, originally @heimer16 only changed it for the "original" version in #910). It also happened in Piper, the "original" G9x was using the G9 svg but the CoD Edition not. As far as I can see it, the devices are identical except that one of them is painted and probably shows up with a different name in the Logitech software.

column21:
Currently I get the following info about the mouse:
$ ratbagctl warbling-mara info
warbling-mara - Logitech G9x Laser Mouse
             Model: usb:046d:c249:0
 Number of Buttons: 13
    Number of Leds: 1
Number of Profiles: 5
Profile 0: (active)
  Name: Profile 1
  Report Rate: 1000Hz
  Resolutions:
    0: 3350x3350dpi
    1: 4450x4450dpi
    2: 5500x5500dpi
    3: <disabled>
    4: <disabled>
  Button: 0 is mapped to 'button 1'
  Button: 1 is mapped to 'button 2'
  Button: 2 is mapped to 'button 3'
  Button: 3 is mapped to 'button 4'
  Button: 4 is mapped to 'button 5'
  Button: 5 is mapped to UNKNOWN
  Button: 6 is mapped to 'wheel-left'
  Button: 7 is mapped to 'wheel-right'
  Button: 8 is mapped to 'resolution-up'
  Button: 9 is mapped to 'resolution-down'
  Button: 10 is mapped to UNKNOWN
  Button: 11 is mapped to UNKNOWN
  Button: 12 is mapped to UNKNOWN
  LED: 0, depth: rgb, mode: on, color: 0000ff
Profile 1: (disabled)
Profile 2: (disabled)
Profile 3: (disabled)
Profile 4: (disabled)

This is an old mouse, and I seem to remember that the max DPI was maybe around 8k or 9k, but I would not trust my memory on this.
But the reported info says current profile has only 3 resolutions enabled, but actually they are all set, and I can switch between them using the hardware buttons.
The color of the led seems to be reported correctly: it's blue.
I now manually edited the device file and updated max DPI to 9600, and get the following:
$ ratbagctl warbling-mara info                     
warbling-mara - Logitech G9x Laser Mouse
             Model: usb:046d:c249:0
 Number of Buttons: 13
    Number of Leds: 1
Number of Profiles: 5
Profile 0: (active)
  Name: Profile 1
  Report Rate: 1000Hz
  Resolutions:
    0: 3350x3350dpi
    1: 4450x4450dpi
    2: 5500x5500dpi (active)
    3: 7000x7000dpi (default)
    4: 8700x8700dpi
  Button: 0 is mapped to 'button 1'
  Button: 1 is mapped to 'button 2'
  Button: 2 is mapped to 'button 3'
  Button: 3 is mapped to 'button 4'
  Button: 4 is mapped to 'button 5'
  Button: 5 is mapped to UNKNOWN
  Button: 6 is mapped to 'wheel-left'
  Button: 7 is mapped to 'wheel-right'
  Button: 8 is mapped to 'resolution-up'
  Button: 9 is mapped to 'resolution-down'
  Button: 10 is mapped to UNKNOWN
  Button: 11 is mapped to UNKNOWN
  Button: 12 is mapped to UNKNOWN
  LED: 0, depth: rgb, mode: on, color: 0000ff
Profile 1: (disabled)
Profile 2: (disabled)
Profile 3: (disabled)
Profile 4: (disabled)

The chosen resolution is reported correctly (I can't be sure about the resolution, but it's the 3rd setting of 5), but if I change it using the hardwarde buttons, ratbagctl info still reports the old setting.  Only after restarting ratbagd it is reporting the correct device state:
$ ratbagctl warbling-mara info  
warbling-mara - Logitech G9x Laser Mouse
             Model: usb:046d:c249:0
 Number of Buttons: 13
    Number of Leds: 1
Number of Profiles: 5

column21:
I still think we should keep the separated .device files.

Looking at @jdz's log it isn't even reported as a different mouse. If it actually is the same mouse (besides a different ID to show a different image in the Logitech software), I don't see why we shouldn't do it.
I already mentioned it, but the first version of this PR only changed it for the normal version. Changes like the LED and wrong min dpi probably would have gone missing for this model like it did with the USB-ID in Piper.
The questions are:
-Are they actually the same?
-What is the dpi range and step size?

The chosen resolution is reported correctly (I can't be sure about the resolution, but it's the 3rd setting of 5)

Can you try to figure it out? For example by measuring the distance the mouse needs to go from one end of the screen to the other and diving screen width (pixels) by the distance (inches), or using something like https://www.mouse-sensitivity.com/dpianalyzer. I'm not entirely sure if that works correct though.
It would be imported to know because looking at your log from #959, it seems like this completely changes the reported resolution.

recognized 8 buttons, but I didn't test them
recognized one rgb LED for the backlight (actually no RBG on this keyboard), which I was able to turn off and on
LED breathing mode didn't seem to work, even though that is possible with the Logitech software
brightness kinda worked, somehow 255 was pretty dim compared to the full brightness in the Logitech software

Would merge (after #931).

[raphael@rphmain libratbag]$ ratbagctl list
cheering-viscacha:   Logitech G413 Silver Mechanical Gaming Keyboard
hooting-chinchilla:  Logitech G703                   
[raphael@rphmain libratbag]$ sudo ratbagctl cheering-viscacha led 0 set mode off
Problem is, I can't turn the backlight on:
[raphael@rphmain libratbag]$ sudo ratbagctl cheering-viscacha led 0 set brightness 255
[raphael@rphmain libratbag]$ sudo ratbagctl cheering-viscacha led 0 set mode on
[raphael@rphmain libratbag]$ sudo ratbagctl cheering-viscacha led 0 get
LED: 0, depth: rgb, mode: on, color: 040000
The backlight is still off.
My device file:
[Device]
Name=Logitech G413
DeviceMatch=usb:046d:c33a
LedTypes=switches
Driver=hidpp20

column21:
So first you need to add device_type to libratbag's device struct, you find it here.
Once that is in place, you need to add a DBus call to ask for the DeviceType. You need to implement a function in ratbagd-device.c (and probably something similar to this) first.
Then you need to add this function to the vtable. If you are at this point, the hardest part is over.
The last thing is to sync up the python wrappers, adding entries here and here.
If I didn't forget anything, that's it. You can take a look at #870, it also adds a property (although not in the .device file) and exposes it via DBus, so you should fine some similarities. Don't worry if you need tons of revisions, I needed them as well.

Okay, pretty neat. Was able to run it. Two more things: you need to add the DeviceType property to the test device, else you will get error: testdevice0: failed to fetch device type.
Also, please print the device type when running ratbagctl device-name info.
Btw, in case you didn't know: you can run sudo ./ratbagd.devel --verbose=debug in one console to start the compiled daemon, and sudo ./ratbagctl.devel -vv --use-existing-ratbagd device-name info in another terminal, without the need to overwrite your system installation.
I would squash the first two commits, and maybe consider using signed-off commits (can be enabled by default in vscode).

Ok so from what I understand I should just keep the enum device_type and get rid of the char* type entirely. seems like a better solution which removes redundancy.
But what should be sent over the DBus to ratbagctl and piper? Should I just convert that enum into static strings in a big switch statement? Or just send it as an Int and let the receiver sort that out?
I storing it as as and enum and then sending a string would be better IMO because that means you'd only have to change it here when another type is added in the future instead of having to change it in all clients as well.

column21:
Hey! I think I got it working. I've added TYPE_UNSPECIFIED and TYPE_OTHER to the enum. When you think about it, all supported devices should never have an UNSPECIFIED type, since that is a required field in the .device file. Therefore I've added 'other' to the tests which would then be used to represent devices such as mousepads or headsets.

  
    
      libratbag/src/libratbag-data.c
    
    
        Lines 56 to 61
      in
      c3de2e2
    
  
  
    

        
          
           enum device_type { 
        

        
          
           	TYPE_UNSPECIFIED = 0, 
        

        
          
           	TYPE_MOUSE, 
        

        
          
           	TYPE_KEYBOARD, 
        

        
          
           	TYPE_OTHER 
        

        
          
           }; 
        
    
  


The DeviceType property is sent over the DBus as a uint32, which will then have to be interpreted as the different types by Piper.
Lastly, I will rebase all the changes in this commit into one when everything is done.

That is the ID of the receiver, not the device. Due to some changes to the kernel driver you need at least Linux 5.5 for the device to be recognized.
Please open an issue if you have trouble getting it to work.
That ID is the receiver, not the device. Please make sure you are running at least Linux 5.5 and see if it's working, if it not we will need to add a device file for the device.
You also have to have an entry in the meson.build file.
Looks like the G304 is the same as the G305. We already have a device file for this ID, is it not showing in your machine?
it shows up as g305 rather than g304
The devices have the same ID, and seem the same. We can only have one name.

column20:
Dicovered in #957
Signed-off-by: Filipe Laíns lains@archlinux.org
column21:
Dicovered in #957
Signed-off-by: Filipe Laíns lains@archlinux.org
@whot turns out the issue was really simple, /etc/dbus-1/system.d did not exist. I blame bad debug tooling! The local circleci runner now works fine, so I was able to track this down.
The config looks fine, but do we really want to add arch linux? Since it's a rolling release distro it could potentially break at any point, for the same reason we removed Fedora Rawhide in  769289f.

Then we know in advance if something breaks. Arch Linux itself is pretty stable, it is just that we use the latest upstream version. We don't package unstable releases/pre-releases. We also keep as close as the upstream as possible, this means that we don't add any extra patches, which are prone to cause breakage, like Debian does, not sure if it's the same for Fedora. From my understanding Fedora rawhide is a development version of Fedora, this means the packages themselves are not stable, contrary to Arch Linux. If I am wrong please let me know.
TLDR: If something breaks for us with Arch Linux, almost all the time it's the upstream's fault (API changes, etc.). That means we will have to deal with it sooner or later, I prefer sooner.
@stephanlachnit fwiw, I've been running libinput builds against arch for ages now and it's always been stable with I think only one build error in two years or so. so the distro is in a good shape.

But the cache persists between jobs. Arch Linux requires a system upgrade when installing new packages after we update the repo databases (partial upgrades are not supported, this means if we update the repo databases we must do a system upgrade before/when we install new packages) and having the packages cached saves us from re-downloading them, which saves quite a bit of time.

between jobs or between pipelines (or "workflows") as circle CI calls them. It needs to be the latter to work but the circle CI docs suggest it's the wrong tool for the job here. Looks like we need caching instead (technically for the fedora bits too).
It turns out using caching simplifies things, as we don't to fetch the packages in the prep_cache step. We already have the cache from the previous job, we install the packages and update the cache.
Don't merge yet.
Okay, great! Everything is working fine as we can see here: https://circleci.com/gh/libratbag/libratbag/4992

column20:
Before this patch, ratbagd would abort initialization of the device because
no profiles are returned.
Once that was handled more gracefully, ratbagd would fail because it doesn't
read the DpiList from its own config file, as no ProfileType is specified.
Specifying G500 as the closest match.

column13: meson: make finding python more robust
column20:
This code assumes that there is a python3 or python3-embed pkg-config
file on the system, which may or may not be true. On Gentoo for example,
only python-X.Y pkg-config files are available and this will fail to
build.
This makes use of the new py_installation.dependency(embed : true) if
possible, and falls back to trying to find a python that matches the
version of python found by the python3 or python module.

column13: meson: Fix python3 version detection with python3 module
column20:
I misread the documentation about the python3 module. The newer python
module puts the language_version in the object returned by
pymod.find_installation(), while the python3 module has the same
method in the module.
Fixes #985

column21:
Okay, so apparently the circleci image for Ubuntu 20.04 doesn't have a timezone set and doesn't set the terminal as non-interactive by default (doesn't make sense to me but whatever), resulting in a installation loop that wants to set the timezone via terminal input. The easiest solution is to suppress an interactive output while updating. Setting the timezone in the circleci config didn't work.
Also, I noticed that we don't need the universe repository since it's already in the default circleci image, this should reduce the installation time a bit.

column21:
@D3SOX you can use a windows VM with swarm installed, but you need to use wireshark and usbpcap, to monitor the traffic of the USB connection. Once you find the right USB connection. You just need to monitor the packets for the Request and Response packets over usb. the remastered ones were around 190ish kb and 130ishkb, but you will see a pattern. Usually it will be a packet that changes only a little bit with every change you make in the swarm client.
Thats the only way I know of doing it.

Hi. I got a Logitech G915 (no TKL). If I connect with USB, its detected ok, but not with bluetooth. I follow the change of the commit and Ive changed:
DeviceMatch=usb:046d:c343
with:
DeviceMatch=usb:046d:c343;bluetooth:046d:b35f
I put that number because this is the output of "bluetoothctl":
Modalias: usb:v046DpB354d0035
After the change, I restart the service but the keyboard is still not detected. Any suggestions?
Thanks!

column21: Sorry. I guess that PR is Pull Request hahahaha. I'm Software Engineer, butI don't know how to proceed here hahahahah. What info do you need in the PR?

Will give it a try.
If I can avoid compiling alltogether: Nice. Overwriting binaries and restarting services shouldn't be problem.
If I have to compile: Is there a simple way to list all the required dev dependencies?

You have to compile this code, no way around that. Here is the wiki entry: https://github.com/libratbag/libratbag/wiki/Building-from-source
But in short for you:
sudo apt install build-essential check git libevdev-dev libglib2.0-dev libjson-glib-dev libsystemd-dev libudev-dev libunistring-dev meson pkg-config python3-dev python3-evdev python3-gi python3-lxml swig
git clone https://github.com/libratbag/libratbag.git
cd libratbag
git checkout -b stephanlachnit/kone-pure master
git pull https://github.com/stephanlachnit/libratbag.git p/kone-pure
meson builddir -Dtests=false
meson compile -C builddir
This installs all build dependencies and compiles the code from this PR for you.
To test it, run:
cd builddir
sudo ./ratbagd.devel --verbose=debug # test if daemon shows an error, exit with ctrl+c
sudo ./ratbagctl.devel --verbose list # list devices, note name of your mouse
sudo ./ratbagctl.devel <device_name_here> info # show device info

meson compile -C builddir

ninja -C builddir

That looks promising! I'll check the compile time warnings later, at least some of them are normal.
The 404 screen is due to the missing USB-ID in Piper, you can check the PR there if you want to test that.
I think the 18 buttons are documented in the driver, I'll have to take a look^^

I compared your compile log with the master branch, and the warnings are exactly the same. However, you didn't compile everything, (with a fresh build directory I get 72 Objects, you only got 64, so some of them got compiled earlier). Can you try to remove your build directory entirely, build again and then try to run ratbagctl.devel?
Regarding the buttons: (>= 9 is second mode)

Regarding the svg: libratbag/piper#540
Regarding the LEDs: the person who wrote the driver eventually stopped working on it, but there is a wiki with some information: https://github.com/hipnoizz/libratbag/wiki/Roccat-Kone-Pure
In this wiki is information about the LEDs, but it's not implemented. If you want, you can try to implement it yourself.

LED

The sinowealth-nubwo driver included in this commit provides

LED support (except for color modes that are not available in libratbag)
DPI and reporting support

The driver doesn't suppoty

button mapping/macros

column20:
When compiling on Ubuntu 20.04 with GCC 9.3.0 and glibc 2.31, I get:
In file included from ../src/libratbag-private.h:32,
from ../src/driver-sinowealth.c:24:
../src/libratbag-util.h: In function ‘asprintf_safe’:
../src/libratbag-util.h:154:7: warning: implicit declaration of function ‘vasprintf’; did you mean ‘vsprintf’? [-Wimplicit-function-declaration]
154 |  rc = vasprintf(&result, fmt, args);
|       ^~~~~~~~~
|       vsprintf
This appears to be because <features.h> is being included by another
header before config.h has been included. If _GNU_SOURCE has not been
defined at that point, then the other macros that control whether
vasprintf is declared are not set correctly.
Include config.h right at the top of libratbag-private.h to ensure
that _GNU_SOURCE is defined before any system headers are included to
avoid this problem.

column13: libratbag-data: log message if the device is a Logitech receivers
column20:
We have been receiving countless issues and PRs reporting or "fixing"
the device IDs because they think it's wrong. Hopefully this will give
them an hint that is intended behavior. If they look closely at the log,
on a recent enough kernel, they should see their device show up with the
internal ID.
Signed-off-by: Filipe Laíns lains@archlinux.org

column20:
The glorious mice uses a single profile. To differentiate between
resolutions each one has customizable color. A led on the bottom
of the mouse shows the active resolution color.
Libratbag does not support a per-resolution color.
To allow adjusting these colors the sinowealth driver defines a led
for each resolution. This is a misuse of the model and will cause
problems when the mouse is added to Piper.
This patch removes the per-resolution leds and hardcodes the led
count to one.

column21: Note that I do not actually own a glorious mouse. I have only read/watched reviews of the mouse and its features. I do have some WIP for adding another sinowealth-based mouse to libratbag but that can go into the next release.

column21: We could export a ratbag profile for each resolution. Every time someone changes one of the shared LEDs (so everything other than the resolution indicator) we would also propagate that to the other profiles. What do you think? Or am I misinterpreting something?

column21:
Yes we could make the driver create a profile per resolution. As you say we would have to sync changes to the shared LED, buttons, report rate, etc between all profiles. Another option is to add an optional color field to resolution and api to change that.
This is yet another case where a corner case does not fit into our model. Should we add a hack like the fake profiles, or support the corner case in our model and take on the work of supporting it all the way in the API, ratbagctl and in Piper? Or just not support that corner case?

column21:
I don't think adding a color field to resolutions makes that much sense. There are definitely some other devices with profiles for only some fields, I think the best way to proceed is to make these fake-ish profiles as they solve the problem in a nice way, I think, and do not put much stress on the API. For eg. my friend has a mouse from Redragon and it only has profiles for the macros, this approach would also fit that. With that said, I don't see this as that much of a hack, it works pretty well IMO. What do you think?
We can merge the PR as is and make these changes later or wait, it's your call.

column21:
I think that using fake profiles will break the users expectations. If I configure a profile in Piper then I would be surprised to see some of the changes also affecting the other profiles.
In my opinion we should extend our model to properly cover the functionality, or simply leave it unsupported. I would go for the latter in this case as I do not consider this feature critical to support.

column21:
I noticed Piper doesn't seem to support more than three or four LEDs (it just doesn't display any controls for more LEDs, nothing bad happens), though I suspect people use only 2-3 DPI settings anyway. Personally I only use two, one for everything, and one with a super-low DPI for the odd console port with buggy mouse input.
Besides not all "fake LEDs" showing up, what problems are you thinking about?
I don't really have an opinion on this. It seems to me like extending the data model every time another oddball mouse comes around will result in a very complex data model, while adding fake profiles is probably rather confusing overall.

column20:
The glorious mice uses a single profile. To differentiate between
resolutions each one has customizable color. A led on the bottom
of the mouse shows the active resolution color.

column21:
The LED model is intended to be for separate physical LEDs on the device. In piper the LED will only show up if the SVG has a leader line pointing to its physical location on the device. Did you have 6 separate leader lines for the fake LEDs?
The problem is that we are exposing wrong data over our API, and we hope that the clients will then know how to deal with that. It will not be obvious in Piper that the 6 fake LEDs are actually different colors for resolutions that all belong to one single LED. We should not send fake data in the API hoping that the clients will deal with it.
It would be more correct to have a LED for the light effects within the mouse, and another for the resolution indicator on the bottom. But then we can only define a single color for the resolution...
I think that we should model the feature correctly if we think it is important, or otherwise leave it unsupported.

I agree.

column20:

column21:
I am not proposing fake LEDs, I am proposing the physical LEDs that do exist on the device but do not have profiles to be exported in all profiles.
Let's take for example a mouse that has 4 LEDs but only one, say LED 0, is present on the profiles. This means if you change LEDs 1, 2 or 3 and change the profile, they will stay the same, because they are not configurable per profile. LED 0, however, is configured per profile.
What I am proposing here is to export ratbag profiles with 4 LEDs, but to match the device behavior, if you change LED 1, 2 or 3 on one profile, they are changed on all profiles.
I do not think ratbag profiles need to map exactly to how profiles are implemented in the device. We are abstracting the vendor API for all devices, I do not think it's wise to try to run after an API design that works perfectly for everything.
So, let's think about how this could be implemented? Adding a LED field to resolutions would solve this specific problem, but not similar issues when only some specific fields are configurable via profiles. What I think makes most sense is to allow extra fields independent of profiles.
How would this look like the UI? Well, I'd say exactly as it would with my approach. I don't imagine we would have a different section for / differentiate these standalone fields, people would change the profile and the shared LEDs would still the same.
With that said, I do understand and respect your opinion regarding the approach I am proposing.
I don't think we should introduce such big API changes, at least not for libratbag 1.0, maybe 2.0? So, for now, let's not support this use case.

column13: Add support for G-Shift keys on g600
column20:
Code implements a possible solution to #598
Overview
Due to the locality of G-shift addresses in the memory of the mouse the G-Shift functions can be accessed via the normal button interface with a minor tweak of extending the count to 41. 20 buttons + 20 G-shift buttons + 1 color register.

Note:  The color register is between the two button 20 addresses so the code creates a "Phantom" button 20 which should not be used.

In order to address this issue of the color address for the g-shift operations the code copies the led color from the profile into the g-shift color address. When pressing the g-shift button you get the same color as if you where not.
column21:
Code implements a possible solution to #598
Overview
Due to the locality of G-shift addresses in the memory of the mouse the G-Shift functions can be accessed via the normal button interface with a minor tweak of extending the count to 41. 20 buttons + 20 G-shift buttons + 1 color register.

Note:  The color register is between the two button 20 addresses so the code creates a "Phantom" button 20 which should not be used.

In order to address this issue of the color address for the g-shift operations the code copies the led color from the profile into the g-shift color address. When pressing the g-shift button you get the same color as if you where not.

column13: WIP: sinowealth driver work for dm5
column20:
This is a WIP pr for another device using the sinowealth driver.
Most things are compatible after I extracted device-specific features (number of buttons, number of leds, and sensor) out into the .device files.
Two difference remain. The color for the main LED seems to be read in RBG format in the current code, while the resolution color indicator is RGB. In the DM5 the main LED is RGB, but that can either be a device specific thing, or perhaps something that has changed in different version of the firmware.
The other difference is the LED modes, where most modes match but both devices has a few extra that the other does not.
In the WIP is also the start of my work on supporting button mapping.
It would be great to get feedback on any breakage on the glorious mice, and to know if the button reading code works there as well. Also any collaboration on the patches and missing parts are very welcome.
TODO for the pr:

 Button read completion (special keys, macros)
 Button write support
 Map extra LED modes

column21:
Very nice, finally a mouse with a similar firmware/protocol! :)
I've only looked at button remapping in my mouse very superficially, but iirc it looked like what you've got here, with simple button-to-button remapping being done through the 0x12 descriptor and USB HID scancodes. Key sequences were stored as variable-length arrays with a separate HID feature report and referenced from 0x12.
RGB/RBG could just be a hardware difference ("we'll fix it in software") were it was easier to route something as RBG, since I'm pretty sure the LEDs in these are driven with PWM directly off the MCU.

column20:
This adds fields to the device struct to store the firmware version on the device. It is also exposed over dbus to the clients.
The firmware of a device can define the protocol or memory layout that should be used to talk to the device. Several devices can query the firmware version via separate commands and we can use this information in the drivers to change behavior of the driver based on the device firmware.
The firmware version is also exposed over dbus so that it is easily available for users via e.g. ratbagctl. It can also be used in piper to warn users that a known bug in a firmware version can cause problems when trying to configure with libratbag.

column20:
Compilation on clang failed as we would try to jump to the 'out' label and then jump over the initialization of a variable with attribute((cleanup)).
We move the initialization up to make sure it happens before the goto.

[Driver/steelseries]
# Actually 6.
Buttons=0
DeviceVersion=1
DpiRange=200:7200@100
Leds=1
Quirk=Rival100

Some more info about DPI:
If I understand they way rivalcfg does it correctly, we have to multiply DPI value for this mouse by 2.33.
This would mean mean that 7200 DPI our software sets would actually be 3000 or 3100 DPI. It would be nice if you could try setting 3000 or 3100 DPI in official software first, then setting 7200 here, and if it's really the same, I could fix this.

I've tested the changes with the latest build ae53f61 and the device file you sent
Mouse showing up duplicated is fixed.
LED is improved. I'm able to change colors but cannot turn the LEDs off (even though in breathing mode it fades from off to full color successfully)
DPI is not working. Every time I plug the mouse in it detects 800DPI in profile 0 and 1600 in profile 1, despite the values set through Steelseries GG in Windows. Also despite what DPI I set on ratbagctl, the info command shows the value I've set but it isn't saved on the mouse, so when I unplug and plug it back in the detected values are 800 and 1600

@RavingSombra, I see, thanks for testing, but it's a bit unclear from your message, does DPI changing work? If it does, I think we can add the device file I sent.
Described problems are limitations of this mouse model. There are no ways to read DPI and lighting mode from the mouse (not that I know of). To disable the LED you have to set it to ON and set the color to black (this should probably be worked around in the driver...).

The DPI settings are kind of dummy.
I can change the speed, but 200-800DPI feels the same. Also anything from 1600 to 7200 DPI feels the same.
Even though the DPI can be changed, I don't consider it's working well enough to consider the mouse as supported (mainly due to the mentioned limitations, including reading/writing to the mouse)
TLDR:
LEDs work totally fine
DPI settings have limited functionality (setting a DPI value only works until the mouse is unplugged or the PC is turned off/restarted)
Mouse buttons cannot be customized (didn't test a config with the 6 buttons tho)
This looks like a duplicate of #1106. I guess it can be closed?
yeapp, push it
Did you test it? Is it working as expected?

@FFY00 Everything is working as expected, here is what I have tested:

Detected by ratbagd
Listed when running ratbagctl list
Detected by piper (haven't got round to making an svg yet)
Able to change settings in piper
Great, thanks!
@FFY00 Sorry about that! All done.

column13: data: add G Pro X Wireless Superlight
column20:
Support for this receiver, and for the device using the powerplay
receiver, still needs to be added to the kernel driver. For now, you can
used the wired connection to configure the device.
You should also not try to use with the powerplay receiver as the kernel
driver does not support the connection and won't forward any input
events to userspace.
Signed-off-by: Filipe Laíns lains@riseup.net
column21:

column20:

Signed-off-by: Filipe Laíns lains@riseup.net
column21:
@bentiss, you may want to be aware of this behavior. Essentially the kernel driver trips when trying to determine the connection type and won't forward any events to userspace because it does not know how to handle the connection.
[915977.398471] logitech-djreceiver 0003:046D:C53A.0107: unusable device of type UNKNOWN (0x0f) connected on slot 1

This is fine on the receiver that came with the device, as we will add support for that receiver together with the new connection type. But for receivers that support multiple types, which right now it's only the powerplay mat, that won't happen. In which case the user could just use the receiver that came with the device, or blocklist the kernel driver.
I am not really sure how to handle this, I will have to have look at the driver.

column20:
Here the driver for the Roccat Kone EMP.
The mouse has four LEDs, eleven physical buttons,five DPI, five profiles.
There are the following limitations:

There is no elevation support
The LED effects is applied to the four LED of the mouse, but libratbag can set a different effect for each LED
The LED effects BLINKING and PULSING are not supported in libratbag
The maximum macro size is 480 events in the mouse software. One event keeps the event data and the timing/delay

libratbag does not keep track of that number of events. It limits the mouse to 128 events


The mouse can repeat macro. Not supported in libratbag
In official soft, we can set a LED color to offset the cycle effect (only with predefined_led_colors).

Since predefined colors are not handled, we can't reproduce this effect.

column21: arch CI failing is unrelated

column20:
See my description of the problem in [1].
Essentially, docker is mishandling the failuire when a syscall is not
available, returning EPERM instead of ENOSYS, and making code misbehave.
The current issue with arch is glibc, which explodes on EPERM, causing
pacman to misbehave.
Once the fix hits CircleCI, we will re-enable.
[1] fwupd/fwupd#2894
Signed-off-by: Filipe Laíns lains@riseup.net
column21:
See my description of the problem in [1].
Essentially, docker is mishandling the failuire when a syscall is not
available, returning EPERM instead of ENOSYS, and making code misbehave.
The current issue with arch is glibc, which explodes on EPERM, causing
pacman to misbehave.
Once the fix hits CircleCI, we will re-enable.
[1] fwupd/fwupd#2894
Signed-off-by: Filipe Laíns lains@riseup.net

column13: libratbag-hidraw: add filter to hidraw read
column20:
Currently, we only have functions that will read and timeout after 1s if
no packets were received. The issue with this is that a lot of times we
may catch unrelated packets, such as mouse or keyboard changes.
To solve this, this patch adds a new set of functions suffixed with
_filter, that will keep reading packets until a valid packet if found.
Users define a filter function and pass it as an argument.
Signed-off-by: Filipe Laíns lains@riseup.net

column13: Add basic support for SteelSeries Rival 100
column20:
First commit fixes report rate changing for version 1 devices.
Second commit adds support for Rival 100. As stated in the commit message, neither button nor LED configuration changing doesn't work. DPI changing works almost flawlessly (can't switch between first and second resolution), but polling rate changing doesn't work fully for now because of #1126.
Edit: forgot to mention: it doesn't support reading any data, including report rate and resolutions.

column13: steelseries: improve v1 breathing LED duration configuration
column20: SteelSeries mice using V1 driver don't support changing breathing LED duration precisely, so it was always locked on 5 seconds. Now we try to match desired duration with factory preset values: 3, 5 and 7 seconds.

column13: steelseries: improve v1 breathing LED duration configuration
column20: SteelSeries mice using V1 driver don't support changing breathing LED duration precisely, so it was always locked on 5 seconds. Now we try to match desired duration with factory preset values: 3, 5 and 7 seconds.
column21:
Main problem (generally a problem for libratbag): the various devices have way too many different options. So when it comes to the public API, you pick what makes sense for most (or sometimes just: many) devices and go with that. It means you can't do certain things on certain devices, but the alternative is to have device-specific configuration tools for each one of them.
So if there's a device that only handles discrete steps for something we expect a more continuous range - snap to the supported steps in the driver and communicate this back to the client (i.e. Piper) so it can update the UI. But unless there's a significant number of devices that only have a few steps, I wouldn't bother having this exported through the API - it makes every client more complicated for very little benefit.

column13: steelseries: improve v1 breathing LED duration configuration

column21:
If we add the ID for the receiver we have no way to tell devices apart, because devices might use the same receiver ID. It also won't work properly if you have multiple devices connected to the same receiver.
What shows up in lsusb does not matter that much, please try lshid.
https://pypi.org/project/lshid/

column20: There are still some warnings, however. More details in #990.

column21:
@b0ywearngtights Sorry, I got confused. The firmware is not actually on the M95512R but in the flash embedded on the microcontroller...
For this you would need to attach to the microcontroller via SWD on the exposed SWD ports and read the embedded flash via openocd.
This is my openocd config on a raspberry pi 3:
source [find interface/raspberrypi2-native.cfg]

# Each of the SWD lines need a gpio number set: swclk swdio
bcm2835gpio_swd_nums 6 12

transport select swd

source [find target/stm32f1x.cfg]

adapter speed 200
bindto 0.0.0.0
Sorry for the confusion, it has been some time...

column21:
I picked up on that but forgot to warn.
The bootloader is hard to extract, the mcu is read protected. The way i did it was to compile a program that dumped the memory through a serial port, and uploaded it to the device as if it was a regular firmware update (we reversed engineer that process)
this is used to calculate the firmware crc used by the bootloader steelseries-crc.py
and this to upload it through the stock bootloader steelseries-flash.py
This is (minimally) risky and complicated

@b0ywearngtights For cases like this I normally install the software to a custom prefix in /tmp. Like meson -Dprefix=/tmp/ratbat and then install it to that prefix. This way you can keep your current installation and don't have to worry about conflicts between both configurations.
Also make sure to stop the normal ratbagd and start the new one instead.

N: Logitech G733 Gaming Headset
I: 3 046d 0ab5
column21: Hum, we could add an option to overwrite the button count and then merge this with the button count set to 0 so that they don't show up. I think that is better than having broken buttons, and allow the driver to even atempt to interact with that configuration. You can base that on #969.

column20:
Led works! I can change colors, mode, duration and brightness.
Buttons dont work, always point to UNKNOW as see above:
screaming-acouchy - Logitech G733 Gaming Headset
             Model: usb:046d:0ab5:0
 Number of Buttons: 8
    Number of Leds: 2
Number of Profiles: 1
Profile 0: (active)
  Name: n/a
  Button: 0 is mapped to UNKNOWN
  Button: 1 is mapped to UNKNOWN
  Button: 2 is mapped to UNKNOWN
  Button: 3 is mapped to UNKNOWN
  Button: 4 is mapped to UNKNOWN
  Button: 5 is mapped to UNKNOWN
  Button: 6 is mapped to UNKNOWN
  Button: 7 is mapped to UNKNOWN
  LED: 0, depth: rgb, mode: cycle, duration: 5000, brightness: 0
  LED: 1, depth: rgb, mode: cycle, duration: 10000, brightness: 0

column21:
Hi, I know this is a bit annoying, but would you mind reverting the merge commit and rebasing on master instead?
Depending on your local setup, it should be something like
$ git reset --hard HEAD~1
$ git fetch origin   # to make sure we are up to date
$ git rebase origin/master

(the origin remote here is https://github.com/libratbag/libratbag.git)

column21:
I tested 85fee87 with my SteelSeries Rival 300 (1038:1710).
Tested:

Setting DPI (ratbagctl singing-gundi dpi set 6500, ratbagctl singing-gundi resolution 0 dpi set 6500 and ratbagctl singing-gundi resolution 0 dpi set 6500)
Setting LED mode on and breathing. off is also supported according to ratbagctl singing-gundi led 0 capabilities but setting it doesn't disable the LED

ratbagctl singing-gundi led 0 set color 000000 does disable the LED tho, so maybe that should be wired to the off mode?


Setting LED color (ratbagctl singing-gundi led 0 set color ff0000 and ratbagctl singing-gundi led 1 set color ff0000)
Setting LED duration (ratbagctl singing-gundi led 0 set duration 10000 and ratbagctl singing-gundi led 1 set duration 10000)
Setting LED brightness doesn't work (ratbagctl singing-gundi led 0 set brightness 100 and ratbagctl singing-gundi led 1 set brightness 100)
Swapping the left and right mouse button

column20:
Set 0x00 report_id for every steelseries device, similar to rivalcfg project
fixes #804
column21:
Everything behaved the same as before, so this patch is fine.
I, like @klausenbusk, and like i experienced before, had issues setting the led modes to off, i ruled out hardware, and setting the color works fine the whole range, but when i set the leds to off sets blue to max and everything else off, not sure what the cause here is, but maybe mapping off to color 000000 is a good option.

column21: Thank you very much for testing this patch, I think at this point we will open a different issue for setting LED off and LED brightness.

column13: steelseries: only use the HID vendor device
column20:
Rival mice are composite devices with multiple HID devices and only the
HID vendor device can be used to configure the device.
Tested with a SteelSeries Rival 300 (1038:1710).
Fix #888

column13: hidpp20: allow setting a default buttons count
column20:
If we can't get the correct number of buttons from a device, we can set a default count.
As mentioned in #1197.
Running info with my logitech g733, with Buttons=0
singing-gundi - Logitech G733 Gaming Headset
             Model: usb:046d:0ab5:0
 Number of Buttons: 0
    Number of Leds: 2
Number of Profiles: 1
Profile 0: (active)
  Name: n/a
  LED: 0, depth: rgb, mode: off
  LED: 1, depth: rgb, mode: off

Other devices print this warning when the file does not have the [Driver/hidpp20] section, is that a problem?
hidraw1: "Logitech G733 Gaming Headset", 1 profiles

(process:68864): GLib-WARNING **: 09:57:16.278: GError set over the top of a previous GError or uninitialized memory.
This indicates a bug in someone's code. You must ensure an error is NULL before it's set.
The overwriting error message was: Key file does not have group ?Driver/hidpp20?
hidraw6: "Logitech G703 LS", 5 profiles

^ warning for my Logitech G703.

column21: IIUC the hidpp20drv_init_device() overrides the count, because it's called after hidpp20drv_20_probe() which fetches report_rate and num_buttons among others. So anything in hidpp20drv_init_device will actually override the value returned from hidpp20 device.

Sorry, but the ID you added is the ID of the receiver, we can't merge this because a different device might use the same receiver, so same ID, causing a collision.
This needs to be supported at the kernel level, I believe there's a PR for that but is stalled, would need to look into it.
That said, you can use this .device locally to use your device with libratbad.
See #1118

column13: tests: test for additonal lightspeed receviers pids
column20: this PR adds test for receiver used by logitech g915 keyboard #1098 (comment)
column21: this PR adds test for receiver used by logitech g915 keyboard #1098 (comment)

Hey, sorry, the PID 0xc539 is a receiver, and thus we cannot include it.
The syntax is also wrong:
usb:usb=046d:407f;046d:c539 should be usb:046d:407f;usb:046d:c539
Also also, the device you are trying to add seems to be supported already:
https://github.com/libratbag/libratbag/blob/3f99446a1be984b78eac60e47bfd66e1c674e30c/data/devices/logitech-g502-hero-wireless.device
Does it not show up in ratbagd or piper?

Indeed, it seems that g502 hero wireless is the same device as g502 lightspeed. My mouse wasn't properly recognized when I tried the first time. After adding the new device file, it started working, but perhaps it was just that this caused ratbag to restart and then recognize my mouse properly.
Anyway, everything works now as it should.

column13: hidpp20: add missing #define to the feature report strings
Add a GitHub Workflow as CI run
column20:
CircleCI is limiting how many runs we can do, which results in pipelines
randomly failing when we've used up the credits for this month.
Let's add a github workflow instead. Unfortunately github workflows are
a bit of a toy api, no support for YAML anchors or extending other jobs,
so there's a lot of duplication needed to get a job to do something.
The actions added in this patch help a bit to make the jobs easier to
understand (copied from libwacom).
This only runs on Ubuntu right now.

column21:
Minor note, I've duplicated the actions to this repo. We could use libwacom's actions directly with
- uses: linuxwacom/libwacom/.github/actions/pkginstall@master

I'm a bit unsure whether we should since I don't want to have to maintain those actions with a public API. But I guess we could just use @sha instead of @master so we don't have to worry about breakage? Not sure yet, any opinions?

column20:
Right now, CircleCI fails with ssh errors because for some reason it
wants to clone the repo over ssh, not https. This is probably fixable
but CircleCI now limits how many runs we can do per month anyway so it's
borderline useless if we do actual developement.
Having to re-learn the Circle CI syntax to fix the current issue is not
an efficient use of our time, so let's just drop this completely, git
will keep the history of what we used to do in the CI for us.
02f3487 added a github workflow which
is comparatively incomplete but could be extended to do the previous
test runs. That's a more future-proof path anyway.

column20:
I'm not familiar with swig and I don't know how to make proper bindings to "ratbag_button_get_key" and "ratbag_button_set_key".
So I made a separate simplified bindings "ratbag_button_get_key_nomod" and "ratbag_button_set_key_nomod" for getting/setting keys without modifiers. Anyway the modifiers are not supported by ratbag itself and also not supported by ASUS mice. So I think it's still better to have than not able to bind any key at all.
I have added "brightness" to leds info with "RatbagdLed.Mode.ON" mode, because you can control brightness in this mode on ASUS mice. I also tried to make "print_led" more readable.
Fixes #1251

column20:
Sorry for putting so many commits in one PR, this would've taken me 10 times longer if I did this on separate branches, though now it would probably take 10 more times to review it :).
Some stuff, for example DPI conversions formulas, is taken from #1065.
Closes #1065.
Highlights:

Improve code style for clarity and easier maintainability.
Support different LED types (RGB and RGB) and different sensors (PWM3327, PWM3360, PWM3389).
Support some new mice: Genesis Xenon 770, DreamMachines DM5, G-Wolves Hati HT-M Wired Classic and Ace (Fixes #1158), Glorious Model O with old firmwares. Detection is based on firmware version (each mouse has a unique firmware version, apparently).
Profile selection.
Printing of currently selected profile, lift-off distance, angle snapping and debounce time.

@hrw, hi, I also added support for Genesis Xenon 770 you seemed to have had a few months ago, could you give it a try? Specifically I want LEDs to be checked, I may have swapped green and blue channels, and also I'm not completely sure DPI is 100% correct (though even if it's wrong it should be ~5% away from intended value in the worst case).
Offtopic:
While searching for firmware versions different mice have, which required me to install configuration software for various mice models, I managed to accidentally update firmware of my G-Wolves mouse to one of Glorious mice. As I had nothing to lose after that I tried firmware updates for some different mice models but to no avail none of them install. And I couldn't even take a packet dump of how the update procedure looks. ;(
I tried to modify the update software, but putting device into DFU mode is as far as I could go. Help would be appreciated.
Now on software level I have a Glorious Model O with absolutely nothing left from original firmware. :^)

Specifically I want LEDs to be checked, I may have swapped green and blue channels, and also I'm not completely sure DPI is 100% correct (though even if it's wrong it should be ~5% away from intended value in the worst case).
Offtopic:
While searching for firmware versions different mice have, which required me to install configuration software for various mice models, I managed to accidentally update firmware of my G-Wolves mouse to one of Glorious mice. As I had nothing to lose after that I tried firmware updates for some different mice models but to no avail none of them install. And I couldn't even take a packet dump of how the update procedure looks. ;(
I tried to modify the update software, but putting device into DFU mode is as far as I could go. Help would be appreciated.
Now on software level I have a Glorious Model O with absolutely nothing left from original firmware. :^)
column21: merged, thanks!

Highlights:

Improve code style for clarity and easier maintainability.
Support different LED types (RGB and RGB) and different sensors (PWM3327, PWM3360, PWM3389).

column20: This basically puts now removed ratbag_old_write_profile in every driver that has not yet migrated to the profile-oriented API. The only other change is that now etekcity driver only writes profile once. While is might in theory be breaking, I think it's safe to assume it wont as I don't think official software destroys EEPROM of the mouse by repetitive overwriting like it did before this change.

column20:
In driver data of hidpp10 and steelseries drivers dpi_list and
dpi_range were allocated with calloc, but never got freed.
Found with Valgrind, I noticed this a long time ago, but never stumbled upon the deconstuctor of driver data where the free call could be added.
column21:

dpi_range were allocated with calloc, but never got freed.

column13: Little pull request for helping gentoo and openrc users
column20:
I was looking for why libratbag didn't work for non root users on my gentoo system.
And I found why:
https://forums.opensuse.org/showthread.php/537468-Piper-not-working
The user need to be added to the games group.
This doesn't seems to be written in the docs.
Feel free to edit this pull request or cancel it.
But please add something similar to the docs or the README.

column13: hidpp20: fetch active profile index only once
column20:
currently the active profile index is fetched for each profile,
this adds unnecessary overhead.
change the behavior to fetch the active profile only once during the driver data initialization.

column13: meson.build: use valgrind only if available

column20:
Make it easier to add new devices by putting devices data into a struct, instead of working with the values manually. This way a person that doesn't understand coding can easily add new data (though they would have to be familiar with building process).
Automatically detect sensor type, and if the sensor type was recognized, set corresponding maximum DPI.
Add support for Marvo Scorpion G961, which has shorter configuration data. Though to use it, a device file for ratbagd would have to be created manually, as another mice with the same VID:PID has been reported not to work (Ant Esports GM500). Incidentally it also has shorter configuration data.
Minor quality of life improvements.
